author: {'steamid': '76561199222642927', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 1250, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 298, 'last_played': 1707983634}
review:
As others have pointed out, this is Invisible Inc. played as the ‘bad guys’. I bought the game on sale, so I think I got a very good deal. It's otherwise too short and non-replayable for the price.

Pros:

- interestingly tactical, given the multiple unit types
- on-the-nose sense of humor, sometimes it gets a chuckle out of you
- an enjoyable and different experience

Cons:

- not really re-playable
- research tree is linear, progression is a bit boring
- UI and interactions can be *very* annoying: right clicking seems to work 3/4 of the time, enemies take too long to move, can't tab to next character while another animation is in effect, etc.
- building on the above: watching the enemy turns can be exasperating on large maps, you spend more time staring at soldiers than make your own moves (e.g. mission 4)
- the game looks a bit ugly to me

Some minor gripes:

- Missions 3 and 6 are far too hard, not a lot of fun
- Enemy paths aren't predictable (as in Invisible Inc.), so player choices have a bit of randomness to them (instead of feeling tactical)

All in all, it's a decent enough game; but if you've played Invisible Inc., then Attack of the Earthlings might seem a bit unpolished. It feels closer to Early Access than a polished, thought-out release. Needs some love to become great :)

review:
一款小品级战旗游戏，玩家扮演守卫家园抵抗地球人入侵的外星异形，开局一虫后，下蛋来战斗，需要避开武装部队的视野来潜入敌营（杀光了也是一种潜入，虫后也需要通过猎杀来攒资源繁殖后代）并完成目标，时不时会出现一些幽默的对话和惊喜的剧情。小异形可以通过消耗资源来向不同品种进化，获得专属能力。难度不算太高，不过因为所有武装部队对小异形几乎都是一击秒杀的，所以如果想避免死亡或者场面失控往往需要勤用SL大法。比较让人在意的缺点是：每个章节开启时会把后续章节重置，意味着重打章节1会让章节2及之后章节中积攒的局外资源清空，到底是想最大限度发展还是够用就好，请自行权衡。
全成就难度不高，只是略微费时。
总体给好评，推荐买key或半价以下入手。

author: {'steamid': '76561198055298567', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 59, 'playtime_forever': 1792, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 966, 'last_played': 1695324470}
review:
I paid 6,74 € for 16.1 hours of fun and I haven't even got all of the achievements yet! This is cheaper than a movie and also has contains much more value!

I reloaded a lot, because I try to avoid any units. If you play more casually, this game should have about 9-10 hours of fun for you!
This game is polished! That means I didn't encounter a single bug or crash!
The game supports 21:9 WQHD ultra-wide. Unfortunately, the "Junkfish" logo and the wallpaper for the main menu are low resolution and look strange in ultra-wide.

The humor fits the theme and is partly brilliant, partly... childish and disappointing. I really liked: The turret (but I feel like there was something missing in the finale) and the birthday cake. I didn't like the names (Pecker, Dickinham *yawn*) and the missing deeper character motivations.
The game is not a lifeless hull, it was made with love. You can see that because of the countless details woven into the levels (references, easter eggs), the hand-written lines and voice acting for the important characters. There are even proper cutscenes (intro, events, ending). Unheard of for a <10 € game!

The gameplay is turn-based and the levels are not randomly generated. That means replay value is almost not there if you are not playing for the achievements. That being said: The gameplay mechanics compliment each other, allow for upgrade choices and are well made.
The turn-based strategy can be very boring though. There is one level with about 30+ mines and you have to wait for every. single. one. of them to rotate on each enemy turn. That was very frustrating.

One major point of critique I have is that you can't access the level menu freely to repeat missions. If I want to get all the achievements for example, I either have to make a save for EVERY level or play the entire campaign again. Because I couldn't just repeat levels, I had to play very carefully, save a lot and reload saves. That felt like walking on egg shells, broke immersion and wasn't fun to be honest.
Another point of critique regarding saves is that the game DOES NOT have cloud saves. I wanted to continue playing the game on my laptop when I was out of town and the game did not have the save files available on the other pc. That was disappointing.

According to the achievements, about 58% of people who own this game actually start it up and about 16% complete it. There is still room for improvement, but for such a small game this is probably quite good.

The game also didn't feel very challenging. Most of the challenge comes from prediction the patrol routes for the guards and hope for the best. So it's basically just figuring out the level structure etc.
The soundtrack was okay, but there was not a single head-banger in there unfortunately. So soundtrack choices could be improved. Sound effects in general were functional and flawless.
There should have been at least one "wilhelm scream" in this game. Unfortunately there wasn't.

I really like this game anyway! It's like a short entertaining novel with a lot of humor baked into it. I am hoping for a part 2 with more evolved humor and sentient turrets!

review:
[code]I bought this expecting a "reverse X-COM", but that's not what I got. But that also doesn't mean that I was disappointed. In the contrary, I enjoyed Attack of the Earthlings! It's just not a "reverse X-COM", not really.
Comparing these games is like comparing Star Wars to Spaceballs and by that I mean everything that follows can be applied to either pair (i.e. the games/the movies): They're not the same. One is goofy and lighthearted and has less substance, but it's easier to enjoy for people who aren't into the deep, complex shenanigans of the other.

X-COM is dark, gritty and has complex base-building and strategic gameplay. AotE is easier to learn since it has less depth/options, a more linear story, and it's undeniably funnier than X-COM... not because X-COM was bad, no, but because AotE is not meant be serious.
(The 1st NPC that you kill in the tutorial is pissing down a mountain path with his back to you while calling his secrete the "wrath of Neptune". The announcements of the humans' administator, which serve as mission updates and stuff like that, are sarcastic and ambiguous, and it's hilarious how he tries hush up the aliens' (your) presence while you devour workers and guards by the dozens lol)

Long story short: If you want a true reverse X-COM (dark and complex), you won't get served.
But if you want a lighthearted, entertaining, still challenging but not hardcore turn-based strategy game that features solid gameplay, strangely appealing gore (like in a Scott Ridley/Simpsons crossover) and black humor, and also makes you lose track of the time, [b]Attack of the Earthlings is the right thing for you.[/b]
(No joke, I just wanted to test it for a short time since I have other things to finish, and ended up "just checking it out" for over 3 hours lol)

It's definitely worth the low price. I even would've paid more for it, if it weren't so conveniently cheap, because imo it's good enough to justify a higher price tag that would suit the game's quality.[/code]

review:
This is a great short game. 

It's a turn-based strategy that allows for many solutions and tactics. Depending on the upgrades you obtain, each level can be played very differently. Everything in this game is well-made: the sound effects, music, and graphics. I don't think I've encountered a single bug. I did encounter some invading aliens, though, but managed to eliminate them all! I witnessed more bugs in the first 5 minutes of playing Diablo 4 than I did in 12 hours of playing this.

This isn't a game you will play for more than a couple of evenings, but not every game needs to be a huge AAA title. I've played my fair share of turn-based strategy games, and this one stands out with its creative mechanics and enjoyable gameplay.

I highly recommend this game, but take it for what it is: a fun, short turn-based strategy game that you could complete in 8 hours. The main reason I spent 12 hours on a playthrough is that I aimed for, if not perfection, then at least something close to it

author: {'steamid': '76561198003418621', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 86, 'playtime_forever': 1132, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 199, 'last_played': 1689614191}
review:
[h1]La porte d'entrée idoine pour découvrir les saveurs du tour par tour tactique: aussi efficace qu'accessible, se concentrant sur l'essentiel avec brio. Une pincée de cynisme et d'humour complète la recette.[/h1]

Acquis contre 2.50 euros en promotion, segmenté en sept niveaux et s'étirant sur une quinzaine d'heures, la proposition se révèle plus qu'honorable, n'affichant aucunes ambitions démesurées pour abattre les cartes de l'humour (parfois noir) et de la parodie.

L'être humain y confirme son statut de parasite ultime: débarquant pour s'implanter et coloniser, décimant les espèces endiguant son expansion puis ponctionnant les ressources lui étant utiles, jusqu'à leur épuisement.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3005578360

Attack of the Earthlings met en scène une société d'énergie intergalactique, Galactoil, dont la nouvelle proie est la planète X13 ; sur laquelle évolue une espèce insectoïde, particulièrement agressive, que le joueur contrôle: les Essaimeurs.

Aussi cupides que stupides, nos colons sont voués à être décimés, assimilés puis recyclés ; afin que la Matriarche extra-terrestre engendre de nouveaux rejetons, se déclinant en sous-embranchements: Grunt (la troupe de base), Goliath (frappant fort et caparaçonné), Disrupteur (crachant une boule de bile corrosive) et Harceleur (posant des pièges). En outre, notre Matriarche est capable de prendre le contrôle d'un individu pour s'en servir d'éclaireur, conservant sa forme humaine mais devenant un légume sur pattes.

En découle un tour par tour tactique, se déroulant au sein d'un réseau de couloirs et de salles, mettant en relief l'infiltration et la coordination des attaques. Le concept est aussi simple qu'efficace, d'autant plus que l’optimisation se trouve réduite à sa portion congrue, se limitant à un arbre d'améliorations plus que réduit.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3004841338

Dans l'esprit, l'humour proposé par Attack of the Earthlings s'inscrit dans le sillage d'une inspiration flagrante: Mars Attacks!. Le cynisme est au rendez-vous, les postures humaines tutoyant le grotesque, notamment celles du superviseur qui délivre des commentaires et des consignes stupides.

La direction artistique est aussi carrée que colorée, sans caractère particulier mais propre, les musiques inspirées s'étirant harmonieusement, en totale adéquation avec le contexte. Une bonne surprise les concernant.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3005577360

L'expérience est concluante, Attack of the Earthlings se présentant tel un jeu d'appoint qui permet de souffler entre deux productions plus denses. Les mécaniques du gameplay sont vite assimilées et les à-côtés sont quasiment inexistants. Un titre qui ne retourne pas le cerveau bien qu'il induise un minimum de réflexion quand l'adversité prolifère, nous invitant à utiliser avec discernement les compétences propres de chaque entité extraterrestre.

Une introduction idoine pour ceux qui découvrent le tour par tour tactique, le titre allant droit au but, sans submerger le joueur, la pointe d'humour rendant l'expérience légère.

[h1] -= 14/20 =- [/h1]

author: {'steamid': '76561198014881208', 'num_games_owned': 261, 'num_reviews': 134, 'playtime_forever': 845, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 845, 'last_played': 1678316566}
review:
Attack of the Earthlings [AotE] is a great little game that I would sum up with four words: XCOM; stealth; indie; British.

[b]1. XCOM[/b]
AotE's basic gameplay will be familiar to anyone who has played the new XCOM games. While it is not exactly the same, the purely mechanical changes are mostly just tweaks. You will be able to pick this up and start playing without a long learning curve. It is also not particularly difficult at the end of that curve if you're an experienced tactics gamer.

[b]2. Stealth[/b]
The main way in which AotE differs from XCOM mechanically is that this is very much about stealth. You move your units around secretively and create ambushes against the enemy. This is aided by most enemy units following clearly defined movement paths. I love stealth so this was definitely a plus for me.

[b]3. Indie[/b]
This isn't a knock. A good indie game knows its limits, and AotE is a good indie game. It knows it is trying to be a simple stealth XCOM game, and it does this well for a dozen hours, without adding unnecessary elements, and then finishes. There isn't unnecessary diversity of unit types, the levels aren't enormous, they haven't wasted lots of money on voice actors. The game doesn't need those things. This is a good indie game.

[b]4. British[/b]
The vibe is very, very British. You know what that means: wacky, sarcastic humour. Perhaps the best analogy would be to The IT Crowd. The pompous corporate boss even looks and sounds a lot like Matt Berry's character. Look out for lots of little jokes in the set dressing, for example by reading screens and information boards.

Overall this is a fun little game. I bought it on sale and definitely felt I had got my money's worth from my play-through. Firm recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561198201620245', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 608, 'playtime_forever': 1927, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1927, 'last_played': 1674141387}
review:
Much love for this TBS with a strong reliance on stealth.

Your female protagonist, in-between a xenomorph queen and a Starship Troopers' bug, purges her territory from the latest British invasion, an evil oil evil corporation run by bickering egomaniacs. Just like the real thing, plus the office turrets.
The comedic story keeps bringing the laughs and the surprises.
The antagonist is excellently voiced by a clone of David Mitchell. Betrays the resources and tech at Team Junkfish's disposal.
Animation, sound, music... all perfect and fitting.

The base mechanics are great: You can consume your kills to increase a pool of biomass, spend from that pool to spawn units, and these units can add to that pool, or draw from it to upgrade themselves to a rogue (traversal, backstab,) a wizard (missiles, illusions,) or a warrior (armor, attack) unit.
Great tactical flexibility.
Plus the values are kept simple and the system beautifully balanced.

The gamepad interface is dandy.
Except in the menus, quite clunky and better navigated with a mouse.
The one big missing feature is a level selector, to replay a campaign level without having to replay all the previous ones. That's a strange oversight.
You can achieve the above from a saved game, by loading it then choosing Restart, so keep a manual save from each of the 8 levels (well, not the 1st, really,) just in case.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997036304', 'num_games_owned': 3192, 'num_reviews': 459, 'playtime_forever': 1599, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1599, 'last_played': 1670304854}
review:
This game has been sitting in my library for quite sometime and it's about time I got to it because I enjoy these kinds of games with a humour similar to that of games like Dungeon Keeper 2, Evil Genius and so on.

In this game you play as the native aliens on this planet that gets invaded by a drill/corperate tower owned by "Galacticoil" who are over-the-top dystopian capitalist company that doesn't care about the workers and the CEO is a fool who clearly failed upwards in his life and had no idea how to deal with real dangerous situations.

The aliens obviously have a reference to xenomorphs and the way the game works is you gain Biomatter by eating humans. Both the unarmed workers and the armed security detail. With this Biomatter, the queen can create a drone that later is able to evolve into three different creatures that have their own strengths and weaknesses.

There is a upgrade tree where you put your points on multiple branching paths. The fun and interesting part of this is that you can save before a mission and turn upgrades on and off so you aren't stuck with a certain build if you find that you don't use a unit that much or if you feel the points could be spent in better places for a certain mission you might be struggling with.

The dark humour is great and I love how the voice actors have played their roles so well in this, but at the same time the game felt a little short as I was having SO much fun with this. I still highly recommend this to anyone looking for a turn-based tactical game with a dark sense of humour.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000582475', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 794, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 794, 'last_played': 1666794800}
review:
Bueno, pues el juego es una vuelta de tuerca al género de ciencia-ficción con aliens devoradores de humanos.
El jugador controla a "La matriarca", un violento alien que busca defender a los suyos tras la invasión de su mundo por parte de la empresa "Galactoil", que sólo quiere exprimir los recursos del planeta y salir de allí lo más rápido posible.
A lo largo de 7 niveles (quizás alguno más), "La matriarca" irá haciendo uso de técnicas de subterfugio para ir eliminando (y devorando) a tantos humanos encuentre por su camino. La biomasa obtenida de los cuerpos le permitirá parir a más súbditos, que le ayudarán en su cruzada contra el invasor.
La mecánica del juego es sencilla, similar a muchos juegos de combate táctico por turnos, en los que los personajes controlados por el jugador disponen de ciertos puntos de acción y ataque, que les permiten usar habilidades, moverse, atacar, etc. Además, el juego toma elementos de los juegos de infiltración, como el "cono de visión" y alcance del ruido para los personajes no jugadores.
Y esto es todo lo que puedo decir del juego sin spoilers.
Repito una vez más que es un juego sencillote, más bien casual. Alrededor de 7 niveles que yo he completado en 13 horas más o menos. La dificultad ni siquiera es configurable.
El apartado musical se hace un tanto repetitivo sin llegar a ser monótono. Creo que 3 o 4 canciones en total.
La traducción al castellano es rudimentaria en algunos casos. No creo siquiera que hayan contado con traductor.
Por último, decir que me lo he pasado bien con este juego. Algunas veces incluso me ha hecho reir. Aunque no creo que vaya a rejugarlo, creo que te hace pasar un buen ratillo, siempre que lo cojas en oferta.

review:
Крайне понравилась эта игра. 
-Смешной юмор

Особенно бесили моменты, когда люди ВПРИТЫК К ВРАГУ не могли попасть.
Но пара минусов у Attack of the Earthlings есть:
-Слишком глючная система загрузок (иногда загрузки были 10 минут)
-Иногда камера улетала далеко за карту и приходилось загружаться
-Слишком быстро проходиться
Но всё же игра стоит вашего внимания.

author: {'steamid': '76561198083930000', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 261, 'playtime_forever': 530, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 530, 'last_played': 1646383007}
review:
에일리언 같은 외계인이 되어 외계 행성을 침공한 지구인을 쓸어버리는 전략 게임이다. 
10점 만점에 7점 정도.



적을 죽이고 -> 적의 시체를 자원으로 활용해 -> 병력을 생산하고 -> 병력을 진화시켜 -> 세세한 전략을 사용한다. 는게 대략적인 흐름으로, XCOM 시리즈처럼 운영파트가 따로 있는건 아니지만 그와 비슷한 요소들을 차용하고 있다. 

외계인의 입장에서 지구인의 뛰어난 기술력를 상대한다는 배경, 나름 괜찮은 난이도, 약간의 테크트리, 탱커/딜러/유틸리티로 분할되어있는 병력 구성, 그리고 각 미션마다 새로운 기믹과 새로운 목적을 제공하고 있다. 나름대로 턴제 전략게임으로서 구색을 갖추려고 한 흔적이 보인다. 

특이하게도 어떤 상황에서든 세이브가 가능하기 때문에, 매 턴마다 세이브해놓고 언제든지 세이브-로드 노가다를 진행할 수 있다. 하지만 그 덕분에 기본적인 난이도는 높은 편이다. 



문제는, 이 모든 것이 너무나도 얇다는 것.
게임성이 너무 넓은 것도 아니고, 너무 깊은 것도 아니다.

적들의 기믹과 전략은 조금씩 달라지고 추가되지만, 아군의 기믹과 전략은 제한적이다. 테크트리가 있긴 하지만, 매번 그렇듯 밸런스 문제 때문에 쓸만한 기술은 많지 않다. 덕분에 결과적으로는 거의 같은 전략이 미션마다 되풀이된다. 

게다가 후반으로 갈수록 더 불리한 환경으로 진행하게 되며, 쉬는 역할을 하는 운영 파트가 없고 전투가 계속 이어지다보니 긴장감이 너무 높아진다. 

전략의 한계 + 높은 긴장감이 합쳐져 플레이어 입장에서는 후반으로 갈 수록 전투가 더 귀찮아지는(지루해지는) 현상이 발생한다.

번역은 완전 개떡같지만, 그래도 아예 없는것보다는 나은 수준이다. 번역하기가 귀찮았는지 띄어쓰기를 제대로 하지 않은 곳도 많고, 어떤 곳은 “베히모스”로 되어있고, 어떤 곳은 “고릴라”로 되어있는 등. 단어도 그때마다 달라지는걸 볼 수 있다.

review:
You're the matriarch of the native species of a planet when suddenly a gigantic space drill lands and gets to work; which you infiltrate and sort of kill your way up the thing. The story is drip fed to you through intercom banter, where the two human leaders mostly play off each-others incompetence as you thwart their plans. The game is a love letter to classic B movie alien movies, and follows a pretty easy plot. 

AOTE is a turn based strategy game with an isometric camera, which is usually enough for people to scream "OMG IT'S XCOM!" despite the game behaving nothing like it. For one, there is no RNG element forcing you to reload saves and pretty much everything works/moves consistently. You start every level with a queen unit, who needs to eat a few folks so she can start releasing grunts into the level, who make up the basic building block of your forces and later evolve into other critters. 

Let's talk about why this game is good. The dry and off the wall comedy works well with the serious murderous advance of the Swarmers. The core gameplay loop of sneaking up and eating people is generally fun, you can even hide and use vents to further bushwhack enemies. Despite being called swarmers, you very quickly learn that you actually want your guys dispersed all over the level to flank the humans on every avenue. I love how the Matriarch is always dynamically entering the level. 

Now the bad. Z E R O Replay value! The game is only eight or so maps with the first handful being painfully linear introductory levels; the enemies and such are all in premeditated locations so there's not much replay value at all besides a MASS of achievements designed to trick you into perfecting the levels. Some of these levels are also painfully short and are just gimmicks native to the genre. 

For instance: There's the traditional early game stealth mission where we have to free the queen from a lab, a timed mission where we escape a self destruct sequence, and a map control mission where we have to stop VIPs from escaping. For those three levels, that's the one thing going on and it HEAVILY distracts from the actual game. 

This brings me to the fact that game would of been slightly better if it had adopted a more open world attitude where you were taking out facilities, hunting for people, and otherwise attacking with a more open concept. Many of the levels are straight A to B affairs with only the final map having a large open concept going for it. 

There's also an "Evolution" mechanic where you do linear upgrades on your guys. It's not actually evolution, and in general upgrades you get are not that good. In fact you can safely just make your queen a killing machine at first, the only time I NEEDED an upgrade what the level 7 boss fight. 


The game is okay, it just suffers from being painfully linear.

review:
cute game but you are overly reliant on melee attacks and only one of your 6 units has a ranged attack though its the same range as the enemies. yes, you need to attack outside the enemies red cone (line of sight) but even then any attack results in a counter (you don't counter though) and all but 2 of your units will die in 1 hit. the main strategy is to distract guards as you try to sneak up on them and using group attack. the lack of strategy make gameplay a bit stale.

LEVELS are ok though there isn't a lot of them. they are somewhat large maybe about as big as an xcom level give or take.

UNITS there are 6 i've seen and 4 can be upgraded with 3 abilities. 1) first is you're main character that can eat bodies then spawn a smaller alien. if you lose her your dead. 2) is a bug type alien that can crawl into grates but its main purpose is to evolve into 1 of 3 other bugs using bodies you've eaten. 3) a spitter type that can learn some other range stuff like distract. 4) an armored bug that can take more than one hit (so 2 hits) and it hits a little harder. this one has a armor up ability and some nice attacks if upgraded. 5) a rogue like bug that can learn backstab (though you can only melee from the side or back, rarly you can front attack by using a door) 6) you can bug a none guards face. these things can distract but will mainly scout though some parts they will just get shot on site. using distract can also lead to them getting killed.

STORY? this is funny and the best part of the game.

OVERALL i feel its a decent game but the abilities do not lead to different strategies. you play the level how the dev set them up and you do not have much variation of what you can do.
5.6/10

review:
[u]Attack of the Earthlings[/u] is simply reverse X-Com. You play the aliens against humans in tactical, turn based combat over a battle field grid. 

But this is a much simpler affair that X-Com. Almost all your attacks are melee. As this would be either too difficult or too simple there is also a stealth mechanic, where enemies have a cone-shaped field of vision that requires you to get flank attacks to avoid being shot when you it's your turn to attack. Yet this attempt to attack some complexity really isn't enough. There aren't many tactical options beyond moving behind an enemy and whacking them. And if that's impossible, either wait for them to patrol passed or maneuver your forces around for the next attack.

Enemy variety isn't very interesting. They all behave quite similarly with variations in their damage and health but little else. There is one melee focused Earthling that does require different tactics, but it's not hard to defeat them either.

Graphics are quite basic. Textures and environments aren't interesting as you move from one space installation to another. Some models are used to liven up the various areas; ATMs in the mall district, stock tickers in the accounting department, etc. but the scenery doesn't change. Animations are very stiff particularly when units are turning.
Sound design is fine and the music is satisfactory. The voice acting however is quite decent if you're looking for English snobbery this game has it in spades.

If this game has any selling feature it's arguably the story, which is mostly a parody of a large corporation with all the usual Hollywood tropes; greedy industrialists that don't care about their employees etc. These are well trod tired jokes, and short of a few chuckles there wasn't much I found amusing.

I don't see any reason to play this over X-Com 1 or 2, which today can be had for a very low price already.

review:
It's maybe not the indie take on XCOM-but-play-as-aliens you're hoping for, but what Attack of the Earthlings actually is, is still fun and enjoyable.

Rather than random missions, the game consists of 7 missions in a linear campaign. There's no branching choices, and missions don't really have many different ways to approach them, so unless you're hunting achievements replayability is a bit low. Even so, the game has just enough ideas to sustain its playtime (took me about 8 hours to complete, plus a few more hunting some achievements) - if it was much longer I think it would be too long. As you can probably infer from that, each mission takes an average of around an hour, so much longer than your typical mission on XCOM or Xenonauts.

Your playstyle will largely rely on stealth, as what few ranged attacks you have aren't great, but in melee your units are very strong. It can require some patience, and maybe some reloading if things go wrong. Given the nature of the campaign, it's been designed with this in mind, rather than being designed with players failing but carrying on in mind.

The humour is very much in the old Bullfrog style, and I wouldn't be surprised if the writers had either worked on, or took a lot of inspiration from, titles like Theme Hospital. It's silly and playful.

Overall, it'll give you a good week or so of fun. The full price might be a bit steep for a lot of people considering how long the game is, but it's well worth picking up on sale or in a bundle.

review:
An interesting twist on who is the monster...

The humans land on your planet, killing your spouse in the process. They are only interested in the resources on the planet with no care about who they kill in the process.

Get the humans to leave... they are the bad guys... but only because their CEO told them to be ignorant. Crash a birthday party. Walk through the zoo and look at all the unknown animals. Have an accountant as a snack...

Good, dark humor, engaging dialog among the humans...

The game is a little short, but the interesting perspective of the game is worth it. 

Be the ultimate eco warrior - but not recommended for vegans without a sense of humor.

review:
So reverse XCom Lite then? What do I mean by that: Attack of the Earthlings (AE) is an anti-capitalist turn-based strategy game, with 6 different units with different abilities. You steer all of them through the oil drill from a megacorporation, and kill every human aboard. Because they are invading and exploiting YOUR planet! It is very easy to understand, and quite frankly a perfect game to introduce someone to the XCom genre. It isn't long for a game of this type (10ish hours), it's funny, colorful, easy to control and with respecable upgrades and unlimited save/reloads also very experiment friendly. Also, for every XCom fan: the setting is amazing. Warhammer or SC2-players might have a bit of Tyranid- or Swarm-nostalgia, while playing the ever devouring swarm.

Since I saw the question in the forums: WARNING! Contains violence against civilians, women, accountants, sentient AI-cannon-turrets and carussell-ponies. No vacuum cleaners were harmed though

Follow my curator at https://store.steampowered.com/curator/28337205-Fair-Minded-Witness/

author: {'steamid': '76561198066066802', 'num_games_owned': 692, 'num_reviews': 68, 'playtime_forever': 551, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 551, 'last_played': 1609062120}
review:
So, as I'm typing this out, I just managed to beat the game. It was not a long journey through this game by any means. That said, it was an awesome one. There were laughs, there was fun, and a neat short story. This is a rather fantastic game.

From the screenshots on the main page, you can piece together what this game is at it's base: An X-Com game where you play as the aliens. Unlike X-Com however, your units are much more disposable. You also don't bring in any units at the start of each mission, only the Matriarch which spawns all of your units as you progress. Which I am a fan of, since it allows for switching up tactics when you need to. And it's all set up in a way that makes it easy to understand.

Overall, I loved most everything about this game. The story is funny, but still cool. The gameplay is simple to learn and fun to play through. I honestly can't find much bad to say about this title. It's not a AAA title or nothin, but for 10-20 bucks, you're honestly getting a very fun 10 hours with this game.

review:
This is another where I wish I could rate it a "maybe". It's a fun little game, great concept, but there isn't a whole lot of playtime or re-playability here, and the art is pretty clearly indy-grade. The basic stealth turn-based tactics mechanics work great, tho, and the game play is mostly really fun, with some surprising depth to it. I'm going to do at least one re-play, to pick up some achievements and try to beat my score on the various levels. 

There are also some issues. I got stuck on the penultimate level for several plays because it wasn't clear I had reached the exit, so I kept looking for it instead of waiting there for the timer to run out. It took a while to get the hang of what I need to right click on and what needs left clicking, too. Finally, I think there's still no way to remap the zoom functionality, which means that if you don't have a scroll wheel (or function that duplicates it, like some trackpads do), you can't even complete the tutorial.

Final verdict, grab it when it's on sale if the core concept looks interesting to you. I would love to see something like this get the backing to get up to X-Com levels of content, but this is just a bite-size version.

review:
Attack of the Earthlings is a nice and funny turn-based strategy game, like the X-com series, but where you play the aliens. I enjoyed the cartoonesque design which goes along very well with the humor of the game. Overall the game isn't very difficult and I would recommend spicing it up a little with your own rules like "zero death" or "finishing the levels before the par turn" (which whill also grant you more points at the end of each level to improve your units) or by aiming at unlocking the achievements. If you're a completionist and want to unlock them all it will give you a bit of "replayability" but outside of that I feel the game is a bit too simple to want to go back and play again.
The game is also very short, I finished it in less than 10 hours and I took my time. Definitely worth it on sales but not so sure about the regular price of 16,79€.
In the end I quite enjoyed playing it and would recommend it if you like the genre and don't mind playing a less punishing variant. But if the punishing part is what drives you in these games then maybe avoid it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004393508', 'num_games_owned': 3487, 'num_reviews': 116, 'playtime_forever': 388, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 388, 'last_played': 1596244521}
review:
AotE is a game about a megacorp drilling oil from the wrong planet: it has aliens on it. Think Alien type aliens. They get understandably mad, and the tutorial mission is about the matriarch sneaking into the company's ship. Every mission is a different floor of the ship (logistics, accounting, marketing, etc) culminating with the CEO's office at the top. I'll get this out of the way now: this game is a linear puzzle with next to no replay value. It's also short! I beat it in 6.5 hours. I watched the finale and credits and have no desire to redo any of the missions/collect the rest of the achivements as the story is over and that's it, that's all I want.

Every mission starts the same way: the matriarch arrives as a single unit, and has to find a way to kill and eat humans so she can spawn more aliens. Aliens come in different types: basic, then three upgraded specialized forms. Your objective is to spread through the level and eat everyone, while also keeping the matriarch from getting killed as that's game over.

This is where I bring up Invisible Inc, as it feels a lot like that: stealth is important. Getting spotted gets you shot, and only a few specialized aliens can survive that. You sneak through vents, hide in convenient closets, set up ambushes, and use the coordinated attack so you can kill 2+ units in one turn without their death screams alerting others.

And, oddly, this is where I bring up the story: every mission features the corp's people realizing what's happening, trying to stop it, and panicking over the PA system. The main character (so to speak) is the CEO's personal assistant, Pecker. He talks a lot, and his dialogue is surprisingly fun as he copes with incompetence while trying to save himself. He's a horrible weasel and I enjoyed finding out his fate. The VAs are good too - speaking characters are annoyed, British, and bombastic. Great fun to listen to!

This leads into every mission being a neat twist so it's not a repeat of the same tactics. The first few are easy, but then new enemies are introduced, or new gimmicks. Every mission has a unique twist that made it fun and/or memorable, and I actually looked forward to the later levels because I knew they'd bring something new to the table, and they did! I've never played an XCOM game where every mission was its own unique puzzle, and it felt awesome.

Now here are the two things that either make or break the game for you: 1) the sense of humor. It's very dry, very droll and also very crude. The first man you kill in the entire game is urinating (which is why he doesn't spot you creeping up on him). The CEO sabotages the security operations because he's too busy watching movies upstairs. Every employee on this rock is miserable, and it's an obscene parody of corporate culture. I almost quit in the tutorial but kept going and it really grew on me with some surprisingly actually funny lines and moments. I'd recommend sticking through it until the first mission is over, then decide if you hate it, as the tutorial isn't the best introduction to the game.

2) The biggie. There are noticeable quality of life problems. There is NO ability to speed up anything in the game. You must watch every enemy unit move at the same speed when their turn comes. Some things are a bit finicky. Also, you cannot see where guards are going - you either have to watch them or guess and sometimes that'll get you killed. Invisible Inc solved this already but oh well, whatever. It's workable, but it just needed a bit of polish that it didn't get. Load times aren't bad but they're just long enough to make you regret loading too often too. Stuff like that.

But if you're willing to be patient and the humor works for you and you're into untangling every mission's puzzle so you can eat every rich bastard inside this horrible place.... it's a great game! It's kind of like if Invisible Inc had handcrafted puzzle levels.

Final note: it goes for 20$, and I forget what its sale cuts typically are, but at this point you already know if it's worth it to you or not. It's 6.5 hours of content roughly, so measure that as you will.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005406191', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 295, 'playtime_forever': 114, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 114, 'last_played': 1594846998}
review:
Greetings as always!  Today we will be looking at “Attack of the Earthlings” a turn based tactical game wrapped in the guise of humor and playing the aliens as the protagonists.   This game should check off all the boxes of a great game…only not.  Let’s Discuss!

We didn’t start the fire:  Let me start on the good things, the game is charming, no doubt.  The graphics are passing but also convey a since of character.  The audio and voice-overs are okay (though they do the Sims dialog style too much) and the game is complete, bug free (as best I could tell) and easily approachable…but it’s so boring!  I greatly enjoy the premise and the humor is spot on, the cinematics are enjoyable but he core gameplay loop just isn’t there; especially with so many amazing squad games out there to play.

Who’d thought the Apocalypse would be so boring:  I enjoy the idea of playing another squad based tactical game.  I enjoy the idea of playing as the aliens and showing the humans as the bad guys.  I enjoy the idea of a tactical game focusing heavily on stealth and sneak attacks.  But why did it have to be so bloody boring!  The gameplay is very shallow, the characters (that you play as) have no depth, no reason to care and the gameplay itself is trifling easily.  The game functions around your Matriarch (which is a nice take) but you spend most of the level sneaking around killing and acquiring biomass, this would be fun if it wasn’t so shallow.  Your units are all characterless but can get upgrades based on points you earn from performance (bad mechanic).  All of said units hold specific functions and the game practically screams at you when you need to use them for a specific function.  The game plays more like a stealth puzzle game and less like a tactical squad game. 

Groundhog Day: After playing for 2 hours I just couldn’t be bothered anymore.  Which is tragic because I love these styles of game, my library holding most of them; I’ve played my share of shallow games that I wouldn’t recommend but still got through them.  I really want to love this game, it has a lot of the core features I should love but there is no depth to this game.  The levels need to be drastically shorted and provided some level of depth because as is each encounter is just a puzzle.  Mayhap I’m not the intended audience; I’m not sure who is but with the reviews on this game I’m sure many are.  I’m not opposed to paying $20 for 8 hours of gameplay, just has to be engaging.  For the cost of many of the more functional Tactical Squad games this game needs a lot added depth wise. 

Overall, if you are an X-COM fan I’d probably pass on this.  There just isn’t enough meat on the bone gameplay wise.  If you aren’t and can live with passable but shallow mechanics with a decently humorous premise then I’d wait for a sale and grab this.  Unfortunately I can’t really recommend it as is.  It is in desperate need of some depth.  Enjoy!

author: {'steamid': '76561198007301352', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 399, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 399, 'last_played': 1586663403}
review:
I had mixed feelings about this game because I was focused on what it doesn't do. That is, it doesn't have much replayability due to a linear design and there is no randomization. But it isn't fair to blame the game for not being something else. Attack of the Earthlings is a short, fun, and funny romp.


A big part of the enjoyment is tongue-in-cheek humor making fun of capitalism and corporations. The earthlings are so focused on the bottom line of their mining operation, the executives shift blame around, the workers are harassed by disciplinary robots and have a timer that counts down when they go to the bathroom. It's a hoot. The aliens spread through the mining ship largely due to human incompetence.


The gameplay is fairly simple. You start each level controlling the Matriarch who, after consuming dead humans, can produce grunts who can be further upgraded into one of three specialist roles. Each level is essentially a puzzle but there are many options for proceeding. I never felt like I had to follow a specific strategy. Casual, relaxing, and not particularly difficult. 


A fun little story of humans picking a fight with the wrong aliens. Lots of small details really bring the game to life. I had this game on my wishlist for a long time but when it dropped to $10, I got it and felt I got my money's worth.

author: {'steamid': '76561198174826034', 'num_games_owned': 347, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 892, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 892, 'last_played': 1581029483}
review:
In Attack Of The Earthlings you embrace the opportunity of playing the oppressed alien natives simply protecting your home planet from the ruthlessly ignorant human invaders, as you claw, stab, pulp, and pulverise your way up the corporate ladder of the Galactoil company and put a halt to their invasion.

Integral to this game is it's sense of humour, akin to Borderlands and Portal in the video game world, and Office Space and Mars Attacks in the film world, with Galactoil (the corporate representation of space-faring humanity) as a pseudo-functioning corporate hegemony operating with a casual disregard for employees coupled with an ironic motivational propaganda machine in a modern office-space environment. There are so many little touches incorporated into the level design alone that really imbue this humour and help world and character-build in what could otherwise be seen as a very short and superficial game. This humour is also more obviously threaded through the hapless characters and their dialogue and interactions with each other and the AI/robots throughout, which as you play gradually reveals more of the antagonist's motives and frustrations as you pick them apart and upset their plans (or just overhear comedic character monologues and watch as robots respond benignly to your presence).

Gameplay is turn-based, alternating between your alien swarm followed by the humans (as opposed to individual mob initiatives), which allows for some fun tactical setups in destorying/consuming humans before sneaking off through a ventillation shaft, or just celebrating Carlos' birthday. You are the Matriarch of the aliens, and as you kill and devour the pathetic humies you can spawn expendable offspring to help kill them in more fun and exciting ways. As you progress, you gain mutagen points after each level, allowing you to mutate your alien offspring into different breeds (effectively: tank, ranged, and stealth units) that you can upgrade further as you go. Meanwhile, the humans inevitably upgrade throughout as well, and with a flexible point-allocation system you're encouraged to experiment and balance your squad according to the mission requirements (or just whatever methodoloy you prefer to apply when dismembering and consuming the human oppressors).

While there are only 7 levels, each one is a uniquely engineered environment, with different gameplay mechanics requiring different tactical approaches and alien units in order to succeed. Each level also progresses the story and introduces new characters and mob-types interspersed through the gameplay and cut-scenes. While the game is short, it has a tight, humour-laced narrative coupled with interesting combat mechanics, well crafted environments and clever/humorous sound-design.

The one down-side is that at around 15hrs it's rather short compared to most other turn-based combat games, and it's a shame there aren't any additional game modes or optional missions to explore as you're very much rail-roaded in both story and gameplay. As such, don't expect anything with the level of strategy, replayability and dynamism of other turn-based games like XCOM, but perhaps expect something more akin to the joy and narrative experience of playing Portal (replace puzzle-solving with turn-based combat). Thanks to Team Junkfish for a wonderfully satisfying and polished game, and hope it gets the wider recognition it deserves.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014723791', 'num_games_owned': 740, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 17, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 17, 'last_played': 1582033119}
review:
The Galactoil corporation's spacedrill lands on an alien planet, aliens get miffed and proceed to wipe out the human invaders.

Attack of the Earthlings garners many comparisons to reverse-XCOM due to it being turn-based as well as being aliens vs humans, although I found its stealth-heavy gameplay more similar to Invisible Inc. 

Its gameplay premise is simple but effective: every level begins with you controlling only the Matriarch. Although a capable fighter in her own right, she is vulnerable and cannot endure sustained combat; her true strength instead lies in (re)production - by consuming the corpses of fallen xenohumans, she can accrue biomass and eventually start creating Grunts. While physically weak, unlike the Matriarch they can traverse the ventilation pipes present on every level; but more importantly, these Grunts serve as intermediaries for more specialized forms: the stealthy Stalker, the tactical Swarmer, and the mighty Goliath. Each of these can be further upgraded between levels, further developing their distinct strengths. While the Stalker is by and large the most powerful (it's stealth-focused after all), there is sufficient enemy variation to strongly encourage the use of other units, and the interplay between them is often quite satisfying, even if not very complex.

In terms of writing, while most tactical games aim to maintain a certain level of seriousness or suspense, Attack of the Earthlings instead adopts a dryly whimsical, dark humor style of writing. A satire on corporate culture taken to the extreme, we see a ruthless but pragmatic supervisor taking more and more drastic measures to contain the alien threat, only to have his plans foiled, time and again, by the whims of a selfish and impetuous superior who is too daft to even realize there's writing on the wall. The writing isn't stellar, but it is decent and managed to elicit a chuckle from me from time to time.

What bogs the game down, however, is its greatly limited replay value and the less than smooth gameplay. Levels are entirely scripted, so there won't be any new surprises once you've finished them once. There are also no difficulty options, and the game is fairly easy, so players looking for a challenge might be disappointed. It is also rather short: there's only seven levels (two of which are basically tutorials), and the game will probably take an average of 5-8 hours to complete; and that would've been fine, were it not for the many unnecessary animations in between each action. The interface is also slightly buggy - the most glaring issue being the inability to cancel some orders without bringing up the escape menu.

-------------------------

To sum up:
+ Neat twist on the genre
+ Good gameplay with satisfying interactions between units
+ Decent writing with dry humor which is actually quite funny at times
-- Rather short, limited replay value
- Not very challenging
- Interface is slightly buggy/awkward
- Quite a lot of waiting in between actions
If you enjoy stealth-focused tactical games (such as Invisible Inc.) and/or British-style satire, Attack of the Earthlings might be worth your while. Recommend getting it on a sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561198172392767', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 3123, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 778, 'last_played': 1586110509}
review:
This is a turn based game where you move in squares, have 6 types of units at your disposal and 4 of them can get up to 3 extra upgrades later on. The story states that you're the alien race of a planet that a megacorp's drill spaceship is trying to drain of it's resources. As the angry alien you are you slaughter your way through their megadrill spaceship deck by deck (mission by mission) from the bottom (workers) to the top (CEO).

The gameplay is quite consistent, follows easily understandable rules and the game never throws something at you that you can't handle. It gets quite hard later on though, especially before the last mission. Still you're allowed to save anytime and as often as you want, restart or load whatever you want. The game begins simple and explains it's features without an extra tutorial for that. As the game progresses you first unlock further unit types and later on upgrades for them that grant them either new abilities or bonus values for certain actions.

In total you have 6 unit types:
1) Matriarch:
-spawns Grunts, the basic alien unit that can mutate into 1 of 3 types of more specialized units
-can't use vents
-can use hiding spots
-can later on receive upgrades to gain extra health, regenerate health, deal more damage, attack once more per round
-main unit, must survive
2) Grunt:
-worse vision distance than any other unit
-least damage of any alien unit
-can use vents & hiding spots
3) Stalker:
-attacks entirely bypass enemy armor
-can create traps that disarm the enemy stepping on or through for 1 round
-can later on receive upgrades to deal twice as much damage by attacking from behind, gain extra AP upon killing an enemy, sacrfice it's attack option for 1 round to gain +4 AP
-can use vents & hiding spots
4) Disruptor:
-only ranged attack unit with +1 range compared to human weapons but an attack so weak that only the most basic or already wouned units can be oneshot by it from a distance; the ranged attack also has a 2 round cooldown
-can also melee attack
-can later on receive upgrades to either lure / blind / deceive (enemies attack another) with special versions of ranged attacks that either cost AP or make the unit unable to attack this round
-can't use vents
-can use hiding spots
5) Goliath:
-+10 damage and armor compared to all other unit's base values
-can use special ability for +10 armor
-can later on receive upgrades for 1 field range 35 damage dealing ground slam, +1 attack per round, +15 HP selfheal
-can't use vents & hiding spots
6) Drone:
-created by your Matriarch turning a non-alerted civilian into a Drone by using the special ability for that
-good vision range
-treated as friendly unit by non-alerted enemies, attacked by alerted enemies
-can distract enemies close by
-can flip switches for you
-limit of 1

*AP = action points

The gameplay mechanics in detail:
-health: visible as health bar on each unit
-armor: reduces all types of damage by it's amount; indicated as icon next to the enemy health bar
-attack damage: indicated on enemies below their health bar along with the number of their attacks per round
-vision cones: different on certain enemy units (some get 360° cones with 3 fields distance, some 180° with 2 fields distance, some 45° 3 fields distance)
-alert states: green / yellow (heard something suspicious and wants to come and check) / red (civilians will flee to the nearest exit; guards always draw their gun now - remains active state for the rest of the mission)
-movement: 1 square = 1 AP; some special actions cost 2-3 AP
-special abilities: cost either AP, your attack move, bio mass and usually have a cooldown of at least 1 round
-attacks: all enemies can attack from a distance while all of your units can only attack in melee combat, except for the Disruptor unit; some enemies have multiple attacks per round; only 2 of your melee units (Matriarch, Golaith) can gain up to 2 attacks per round via upgrade later on, all others only have 1 attack per round
-vision: all units have a some squares ranging vision area, even through walls; only the basic grunts have actually bad vision range
-bio mass: gained by devouring enemy corpses; used to create your alien army by spawning Grunts from your main unit (Matriarch) at the cost of 4 bio mass; you can chose 1 of 3 unit types to mutate a grunt into
-mutagen: upgrade resource that's awarded at the end of a mission; you get more the better your mission performance was (fewer turns, no losses etc.)

The core gameplay is mainly about positioning, managing your actions, taking out single enemies efficiently and surviving each mission to get to the next. For groups of enemies you get disruptive abilities later on, mostly with the Stalker and Disruptor but sight-breaking level architecture can also help with that. Additionally to take out multiple enemies without triggering an alert there's the team action, which sadly only works for melee attacks, and lets multiple attacks of your units happen at once. This allows you to either take multiple enemies without one noticing the attack on / death of the other and triggering an alert or to kill a single strong enemy instantly by surrounding that unit with multiple of your units. The game's UI is quite clean and simple: You've got your action buttons per unit that you can either click or bind a hotkey to. Same for tabbing through your units back and forth. The only thing I missed at times was a map of all that I already had explored along with where my units are. The camera can be turned 90° 4 times. Each of your unit's actions forces some waiting time until it's performed before you can order the next unit to do something. All ingame cutscenes are skipable. The only thing you (sadly) can't skip is watching enemy movement inside your vision distance - that's always shown per enemy unit and can't be skipped.

I haven't encountered a single bug or issue in my playthrough aside from sometimes needing to adjust my camera view a bit to be able to click corpses to devour in corners. One thing I noticed, however, was a 6 GB RAM and 30% CPU drain solely by this program after playing it some hours. That's a lot for what it actually features.

Overall I recommend the game. I had fun, for me it's a good game. As always: not every game is for everyone. It's a turn based game with a gameplay of strategically taking out single enemies and some humor along with a main story that progresses through the missions. If you want some further impressions then either watch some gameplay videos made by other people or get it on Steam - but stay below the 2h gameplay time to still be able to get a refund.

PS: Carlos missed his performance review.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048976151', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 620, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 620, 'last_played': 1576862041}
review:
Let me start this off by saying that this game is better seen as a stealth puzzle game rather then an x-com game!
And I think the steam page should put more emphasis on that. Although it mentions that it's a stealth game.

Pros:
- Unique way of getting units and gaining your resource biomatter
- It realy makes you feel like an alien infiltrating a human spaceship or base. 
- Visual design is comical simple but good. As an example: Vents have "VENT" written over them in huge letters. How can that not be hillarious but also draws your attention in a "look, you have this option" way.
- Abilities are well explained and easy to understand. Movement path effects, enemy vision and ranges are easy to read (not like xcom where you never know if you can hit an alien of if that fence post shaves of 90% of your accuracy or where you dont know if the enemy will see you when you sneak up on their back!)
- You can always do better. While the levels are static, you get a score at the end, which you can always try to improve.

Con:
- It's easy. Especially for xcom veterans and the like it's way to easy. While it's more puzzly then strategy, that also means the game can feel like a chore.
- While they are easy to use, Controlls are not what you'd expect from a game like this. You need to double click many things that should need single clicks, and it's easy to forget options or units you have around because it doesn't ask you to do anything with them. Worst is that the movement point counter (which is used for many abilities too) isnt displayed on the unit icon. Only on the unit itsself. And only if it has any left.
- You dont get the option to replay a level once you've pressed "continue" after finishing it. Which makes story sense, sure, but it is frustrating in a first time playthrough when for your first and second level you didnt get many points (which are used to unlock new abilities for your units) and you're always shy of 100-300 points for the rest of the game to get one more ability because you didnt get those points at the start cause you didnt know what the fuck you were doing!
- The levels are set. There's realy not any variety with playthroughs aside of you having more knowledge about the level and how to play the game. Thus you might not play it more then 1 to 3 times ever. The lack of more then the 3 units (of which 1 is a must use because it's the only ranged one and the only one with a lure) you have very little freedom in "army" compositions to go with. (combo of the Stalker with double dmg backstab and the disruptor's lure and range will beat anything except bosses in one hit. And the Stalker is the cheapest to upgrade and evolve a grunt into.)
- A price of 20$ is a little high I think. But it's not overly overpriced. And steam sales exist on anything bit the newest game. So this isnt as bad.

In the end, I would definitely recommend this game when it's on sale! 
It's a simple game and a lot of simple fun. Definitely worth playing through once if you like the alien movies, like stealth games or easyer turn based strategies.
But the main appeal of the game is just silly fun and enjoyment of being an alien group, sneaking through a base eating people to grow stronger, and finding many little simple comical jokes or laughing at the stupid humans.

author: {'steamid': '76561197988000877', 'num_games_owned': 1605, 'num_reviews': 240, 'playtime_forever': 491, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 491, 'last_played': 1576202060}
review:
Long story short, this is good dumb fun. Both narratively and mechanically this game is one-note.  But it consistently hits that note, and rarely outstays it welcome.

I've seen alot of comments comparing it to X-Com, but I'd say that it gives the wrong expectations. This feels more like a puzzle game dressed in a tactical paint job. There is a handful of set stages that you'll need to stealth your way, spawning the correct alien for each job, killing the humans in the correct manner. While you can vary some from the "Correct" path, it'll cost resources that you may need for an enemy down the line.

Despite it being a linear puzzle, it feels very good.

The rules are simple to learn so that you're constantly making informed decisions. You've planned each ambush, everything went according and you feel like the monster stalking the halls. By the end of the third stage you've mastered everything you need to beat the game, and while each of the 4 units has an upgrade path... few actually change the game.

But there were a few situations that dulled the experience, a few specific stages where I found myself frustrated or annoyed by the tedium required for something. Specifically, the pathfinding tended to fail in one mid-game stealth section and one late game minefield. I needed to micromanage it one step at a time. 

But these were exceptions in the experience. Most of it was well paced, with just enough humor to keep me smiling. It's not deep or engaging enough that I'll likely ever play again, but it was good enough that I wanted to finish the game at least once.

author: {'steamid': '76561197982851613', 'num_games_owned': 1196, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 427, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 427, 'last_played': 1575829537}

+ Юмор.
+ Уровни. (Считаю, что уровни достаточно проработанные и видно, что ребята очень старались над ними)
+ Есть разные войны и у всех есть своя ветка прокачки. (т.е уровни можно проходить каждый раз по разному)

их всего несколько:
- Игра достаточно короткая, хотелось бы увидеть продолжение. (На прохождение ушло 8 часов)
- Во время кат сцен, или новых ходов, к сожалению нет какого-то переключения, или отображения всех юнитов на пользовательском интерфейсе, из-за чего нельзя выделить, или переключаться между юнитами, а после хода, нужно их искать по карте. 

Хотелось бы увидеть продолжение, игра понравилась.

review:
エイリアンとなって、侵略者＝人間を駆逐するタクティカルストラテジー。1体のボスエイリアンと、様々な形態に変形できる子エイリアンに指示を下し、なるべく見つからないようにしながら敵を倒し、食べてエネルギーに変えて行く。一見XCOMぽいが、ステルスメインで、どちらかというとInvisivble Inc.に近い。

まだクリアはしていないがプレイ時間が10時間を越えたのでレビューを。

数多くあるタクティカルストラテジーだが、プレイヤーキャラがエイリアンという視点は新しい。敵（人間）を倒して食べることによってエネルギーをため、子エイリアンを作ったり、進化させたりできる。進化は遠隔、暗殺、大型のそれぞれ独自のスキルをもった3タイプ。遠隔能力を持ったもの以外は近接のみなのも特徴。武装した敵に見つかるとほぼ一撃でやられるので、とにかく見つからないように行動しながら、敵の背後を取ったり無力化したりして仕留めていく。少々敵に見つかっても近くの敵以外は反応しないので、ステルス感はInvisivble Inc.ほどシビアではない。

シナリオマップを順に進んでいくが、マップの構造や敵は固定で、マップ数も少なく、ランダム要素はほとんどないので、再プレイ性は低いかも。隠れたり後ろから追いかけたりしながら人間を追い詰め、エイリアンとして振る舞うのは、それっぽくてなかなか楽しい。日本語に対応しているし、難易度もそんなに高くないので、カジュアルにちょっと変わり種のステルスタクティカルを遊びたいという方に。

★★★☆☆

review:
A simple and charming turn-based stealth game from the 'evil'/alien perspective. Recommended if you want a short and fun game or you're into this genre. Newcommers are probably going to be a bit frustrated by some of the "clunkyness" , but overall I'd say it's a pretty good game.

+ Gets the core mechanics right; character classes complement each other well and the stealth mechanics are easy to understand and straight forward.
+ Silly and charming humor, doesn't take up too much of the time or get in the way of the actual game either
+ Reasonable amount of content for the low price I paid for it (17euro)

- It's got a somewhat dated or low-budget look to it at times.
- Kind of clunky and slow animations. I found myself "waiting on the game" a bit too much.
- Somewhat sluggish UI. For instance, I have to double click when it's not intuitive to do so, you can easily hit the wrong tile/thing because something is obscuring the view, little feedback when you're aiming at things - that sort of thing. I got past it, but it was a little frustrating at times.

review:
BLUF: This is a very short game.  It took me a six hours to beat the campaign and I didn't rush.  I paid $10 so I feel I received a fair value for the amount I paid.

You play an alien Matriarch which spawns additional aliens as you consume human corpses which you use to make more human corpses...  It is hard not to like the concept.  The combat is turn-based on square tiles.  The research system is very limited (13 advancements which are applied between levels).  I found the homour bland but that may have been my mood at the time.

Ultimately, I feel that this game was more of a problem solving game than a strategy game.

Pros:
- Concept

Cons:
- Very short
- Repetitive music
- Linear level design
- No replay value

author: {'steamid': '76561197991017265', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 77, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 77, 'last_played': 1568601664}
review:
I want to like this game, I really do -- The concept is novel, and I enjoy turn-based games like this -- but I just can't get into it. The mouse controls for performing actions are inconsistent, and not clearly explained. That I could tolerate if the story was good enough, but since the story is weak, it starts to grate.

It starts to grate a lot.

Like, a LOT a lot.

The humour that isn't toilet related could be summed up as "Durr, humans are stupid TOTALLY ALL THE TIME! Tee-hee-hee! Oh yeah, before I forget: PEE!"

Don't get me wrong, I don't mind "low-brow" humour, and I don't want to sound elitist, but there's gotta be something more... I dunno... Interesting...

I went in with the impression that the game would have some justification for this monster to want to defend its homeworld from this human invasion, but it turned out (at least on the first floor) that that justification was that the guy in charge was just an arrogant middle-manager, promoted to the level of his incompetence. Honestly, I started to feel sorry for the poor peons I was slaughtering.

Maybe it gets better as the floors progress, but one hour in, and (apparently) 1/7th of the way through the game, I can't bring myself to start it again.

Again, I want to like this game, but I just don't...

author: {'steamid': '76561198000896253', 'num_games_owned': 697, 'num_reviews': 212, 'playtime_forever': 439, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 439, 'last_played': 1558647901}
review:
This indie game came on my radar a while back when I utilised Steam’s Discovery Queue. Basically, it is turn based tactical battles (think X-Com minus the % to hit), but it isn’t on procedurally generated maps, instead there are set levels to get through.

As you may have surmised from the title… the game focuses on the Aliens instead of the humans. You are the Matriarch of an alien species. I’ll be honest, they’re totally inspired by the Alien movies, but that’s okay, they give their own spin on it.

Anyway, a human galactic mining company decides to land on your planet and on top of some of your kids. So, as any upset alien mother does, you get on their drill-spaceship and start slaughtering the humans in retaliation.

You get to utilise a few tricks, hiding in storage areas, utilising vents to lay out ambushes. Most of your units are melee focused, so planning is necessary, especially since humans have nice big guns. There’s even a storyline here, believe it or not, told via the PA system on the ship, usually from the men in suits wondering what the hell is going on.

Surprisingly, dialogue in this game is quite funny, there were more than a few clever one liners and more than a few moments that had me smiling. The aliens themselves don’t talk at all, they’re killing machines after all, so it is funny listening to the incompetent human corporation and their reactions to your bloodbath. For those of a keen eye, there’s a few environmental jokes as well.

All in all, there are 7 levels to get through. You have access to five different unit types, three of which are specialised for their own style of combat. You get to upgrade these as the missions go by and you can spawn them via biomass, which is gained by chowing down on human bodies.

If you’re up for a turn based game where you play the aliens, and you like amusing dialogue, check this one out, it really did take me by surprise, however given its length I recommend picking it up at sale price. 7/10

There is a video game titled "X-Com: Enemy Unknown." Attack of the Earthlings plays exactly like that except the rolls are reversed. Every enemy and ally has a turn to take and things must be planed out strategically ahead of time as timing in this video game is important. Gore is almost nonexistent, violence is of the level of most cartoons for the kiddies, but the language for sure earns this video game a rating fit for teens or adults.
The one REAL downside is they use that r-e-t-a-r-d-e-d "engine" called Unity. It is evident all over from the lack of multiple events, the inability to remember scene changes after reloading a "saved" session, and my favorite evidence (sarcasm) the cheaply animated movies or "cut scenes" that look like paper or cardboard with just the camera changing angles to give the appearance of subtle movement. A cheap trick used by a cheap "engine." It's like the Socialists/Democrats: they claim everything is happiness and have brainwashed other idiots to zealously fight FOR them, but when you see it in action it never fails to disappoint performance-wise.
Junkfish can be credited with making the most out of nothing and they did. A fun adventure, that can just as easily be titled "Attack of the Soyboys." Either way, it is the duty of the superior species to wipe out the infection. Denny Crane.

author: {'steamid': '76561198201808462', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 303, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 297, 'last_played': 1694108325}
review:
pretty good turn based stealth/strategy game! the story is a relatively by the books alien invasion one, although playing as the aliens (who are being invaded by humans) is a cool twist on the formula, and the humour is pretty good, in my opinion very rarely falling flat.

the 5 "classes" of alien (as well as the "assimilated humans") feel varied and entertaining, and the different enemy types force you to think about which classes you spend biomass (gained from eating corpses) on, as well as what you do with them, rather than just spamming whatever you want. the upgrade system for them is fun although unfortunately pretty linear. i would have liked to see branching paths to further specialise them. 

the missions are all fun, and again feel pretty varied, with objectives ranging from "kill everyone" to "escape the level currently being vented". my one problem would be that they dont seem massively replayable, aside from trying to reduce the number of turns the mission took you to complete, as the map layout/objectives/enemy types don't change on new replays.

review:
I had a lot of fun with this game. I wasn't expecting too much, but it really came through.

+Strikes a great balance between stealth and xcom-style tactics that I wish more games had.
+Level design and humor takes a lot of the best elements from classic games from the late 90s.
+Achievements hit that sweet spot of being interesting and making you want to play some more, without being a huge hassle.
+Being able to grow and enhance your "squad" over the course of the level is really satisfying.

-Maybe a little cheesy for some tastes
-Maybe a little slow-paced for some tastes?

I definitely recommend it as a very solid indie title if you enjoy stealth games and/or tactics games.

review:
很不错的策略游戏。

优点：
“反人类”剧情，本地人英勇抗击“外星人”侵略的励志故事，而且“外星人”一方被黑色幽默的方式刻画得很是迂腐XD
机制很简单，教学也很通俗易懂。
最后结局动画(PPT)很赞。

缺点：
无限SL求得更优解是这种游戏的常规操作，但是读档时间有点长+每次都得看一遍所有视野内敌人的行动有点等得难受（尤其是地雷关...）
有时平民的行动模式很奇怪；而且人类视野占了半个格子的时候，有时能看见有时就没事...
然后，貌似这游戏通关后没法直接重玩某个章节，貌似只能重头打...让我这种不喜欢打二周目+100%成就强迫症很是难受...

author: {'steamid': '76561198021141277', 'num_games_owned': 946, 'num_reviews': 279, 'playtime_forever': 443, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 443, 'last_played': 1558389069}
review:
Attack of the earthlings is a communist propaganda game in which you must employ your basic worker comrades to defeat the british capitalist imperialistic machine of oil tycoon company "Galactoil". To do so you must slowly but surely seize the means of production of the entire ship/driller/offices that the game takes place on, starting by convincing the basic oil rig workers and civilians of the wrong in their ways to conver them to glory mother Alien Russia and then proceeding to behead and defeat capitalist pigs that only want their interests in spite of the common worker.

The game is turn based, its cool. The point of the game is the mechanic that your entire life depends on your "matriarch" unit, which is the only one that you start with in each level from which you can spawn grunts, that then proceed to convert into one of the 3 units in the game, the rogue, the ranger, or the knight. As simple as this sounds this ends up with a lot of depth in later missions considering you cannot change one units class at all, and you are left with having to spawn another one at the cost of your "biomaterial" that you get by eating dead humans and recycling some of the dead aliens of yours.

There is 0 replay value, no NG+, no online features, no DLC, no side missions, no cloud saving. Unless you really like the game there is no reason at all to play it again and other than the achievements there's nothing separating it from a typical pirate copy. Although considering its budget i do not think much more is required. The game is good nonetheless. And it was made in Unity!

The game is FULL of british comedy to the point that if you aren't fond of it you are just gonna find the comedy and the writing obnoxious. If you DO like british comedy, the game is gonna be right up your back alley. It swims in it.

The game is hard. Not impossible but it IS hard.

Any negatives to the game? Yes. Waiting to see the AI's moves gets to be WAY too cumbersome, specially when you have near total vision which  makes the camera jumps around all the time and you have to wait for it to focus before the AI even moves, and specially when ther'es a lot of enemies in the map, making the wait time even longer. I kinda wish it did like Xcom or Xenonauts and made the enemy movements hidden to cut time. But beyond that, there's no real obvious negative point to the game. The artstyle is fine and stylized.

Game obtained for free in the Chrono.gg coin trade shop.

author: {'steamid': '76561198053392309', 'num_games_owned': 401, 'num_reviews': 130, 'playtime_forever': 728, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 716, 'last_played': 1557601407}
review:
Wer ein neues X-COM erwartet, sollte die Finger von Attack of the Earthlings lassen und stattdessen X-COM spielen. Auch die ach so andere Ausgangslage, dass man die Aliens spielt und nicht die Menschen, macht an sich erstmal keinen großen Unterschied. Sie ist allerdings Basis für einige interessante Spielmechaniken, wie die Alienkönigin, die, wenn sie genug zu fressen findet (tote Menschen, tote Aliens, ihr ist das egal), Nachwuchs gebären kann, sowie den großartigen Humor über die Firma mit dem großen G und ihre Abteilungen, die das ganze Problem erst ausgelöst hat. 

Wer also Gefallen finden könnte an einem eher "kleineren" Spiel mit einem düsteren Humor, ein paar netten Mechaniken und eben rundenbasierter Taktik, der ist bei Attack of the Earthlings gut aufgehoben. Nach anfänglicher Skepsis hat sich bei mir der bekannte "Nur noch eine Runde"-Effekt bewirkt, der mich sogar allzu lang von der Kaffeemaschine ferngehalten hat - und das will was heißen!

Attack of the Earthlings lief bei mir problemlos unter Linux.

review:
It's a rather short game (just 7 levels), but quite nice indeed. A lot of this is due to the voice acted scenes which are quite fun -- there are only two voice actors so all the characters that are actually in the game only have speech bubbles, but the PA lines that occur at important points are hilarious.

It's a strictly round based game, with units (there are only 5 of them) having "action" and "attack" points to spend on each round. It's not difficult either -- I never failed a level, and completed the optional objectives on most of them as well (the only exception being the timed level that had to completed in a certain number of rounds).

Later levels can be a bit slow -- enemies move one by one, including things like rotating mines, and the game diligently scrolls to each visible enemy unit to show you the movements.

review:
Expected an X-Com style game, but to my surprise it turned out to be more of a Commandos / Desperados / Shadow Tactics style game!

Playing as the Matriarch, you devour humans and use the resource you get to produce your hive on each level, and figure out how to best use each of your type of creatures to defeat each level of the human corp. station.
The game also has a sort of customization where you can unlock skill for your unit as well as improve their combat abilities.
Which can be key to make certain levels much more doable. 

I did not expect the amazing dialog filled with humor and comedy, it's fantastic.

If you expect something like X-com you might want to look elsewhere since while the turn-based mechanics are similar, they are not the same genre of games. As I said, this is more like Commandos or Shadow Tactics. 
If you are looking for that, or like a humorous twist on the alien vs humans genre, you will enjoy your purchase. 
The game isn't too long though so it might be a bit pricey for some maybe. it's a must buy on a sale though.

review:
Attack of the Earthlings ist eigentlich eine Art Puzzle-Spiel im XCom-Kleid. Da ich beide Genres mag, war es für mich eine tolle Spielerfahrung.
Das Spiel hat einige Ecken und Kanten und man merkt deutlich, dass es eine Indieproduktion ist u.a. am Umfang (nur 2 Personen synchronisiert) oder an gewissen technischen Makeln (Maussteuerung manchmal etwas fummelig). Aber nichts davon ist tragisch und wird durch das motivierende Gameplay, die gut gemachten Levels und den witzigen Humor gut wett gemacht. Und mit rund 8-12 Stunden hat das Spiel auch eine ideale Länge und endet bevor es zu repetitiv wird.

Fazit: Ein kleines aber feines Spiel, das nicht besonders fordernd oder ewig komplex ist, aber für ein paar Stunden beste Unterhaltung bietet für Fans de XCOM-Mechanik.
