review: So what can i say about Attack of the Earthlings really? Well let me start off by saying this game has a ton of personality and it will make you laugh at times. If you're a Sci fi fan like me, you've probably tried one of those classic sci fi horror/action games where you're playing as an astronaut on a space station trying to avoid getting eaten by some alien scum. Well in this fun and exciting strategy game it's pretty much the exact same type of scenario but you're playing as the aliens. There's not really much of a story to this game. Basically a massive company and it's rich owner has decided to mine your planet for resources cause why the fuck not? And you, the leader of the alien race doesn't exactly allow outsiders inside your territory. So you do the most rational thing and start assassinating the average joe workers of this massive company, then use their biomass to produce an army of lower lifeforms under your command to assassinate even more humans! :D You can create 4 different unit types and they're all totally unique creations with special abilities that fit different playstyles. In the beginning i thought i had to use all 3 different evolutions (Out of the 4 creatures you can spawn 1 of them is the default non-evolved alien drone) but it turned out that you should really only stick to the xenos that suit your personal playstyle. I didn't hear about this game from some big youtuber, or anything. I just happended to get it recommended by Steam one day and thought ''hey that's a neat concept and it's on sale!'' There's also a small progression system in the game that allows you to upgrade your units and give them new and improved abilities. The game takes about 11-12 hours to finish if you're just doing a casual playthrough and you fail a few missions (Like i did) Each mission is really fun cause no mission has the same objective. There's no difficulty options in the game, and there's unfortunately no new game+... This is the bad part of the game, you see you can't replay levels unless you have an old save file right before the level you want to play. If you don't then you need to replay the level until you get to the level you want to replay. However there is only about 7-8 levels in total so it's not like getting to a specific level is hard. Each level feels new and unique due to each level having it's own objectives that are all totally different from one another. Overall i'd give Attack of the Earthlings a solid 7/10. Would recommend, even at full price if you're into strategy games and don't mind the low difficulty. Now go out there and nom some humans >:3

I am a sucker for turn based games.  I can't recommend this game.  The missions are boring and uninspired.  There are also mechanics that are questionable.  Like line of sight, the alien (which is you) is right in front of of the enemy, but because the line of sight of the enemy spans 4 tiles, You are virtually invisible.

There is already a major crisis and yet they don't ask all the soldiers to converge to a position.  I mean, with that kind of space faring superior technology, you don't have proper cctvs or communications.  Also, there are red alert alarms going on, and yet scientists are still oblivious in their surroundings.

Why is the conversation of the CEO and the assistant over the PA system, it doesn't make sense.

The only shining moment is the sometimes funny humor.

TL/DR: Skip, there are better turn-based games there.

I regret getting this game.

[h1]人類貪婪的飛行船降落異星球準備探勘，異形蟲后帶領她的子民群起反抗！[/h1]

[code]Attack of the Earthlings 是一款看似 XCOM 的回合制策略遊戲，實際上玩起來也確實很像，至少在戰鬥這塊有著類似的架構設計，但規模與格局上沒有那麼大；遊戲充滿黑色幽默的劇情橋段，讓這款扮演異形獵殺人類的作品，在血腥殺戮之中帶來不少歡笑的元素。[/code]

[h1]遊戲特色[/h1]
在「地球人入侵」中，我們可以透過扮演蟲后體驗到異形的頑強性，遊戲內殺死的所有敵人，都能被連皮帶骨吃的一乾二淨，而吞噬敵人獲得的生物質，可以讓蟲后孵化出新的異形單位，也能用來進化幼蟲單位，成為三種不同戰鬥風格的成蟲單位。

戰鬥的進行方式類似 XCOM，但這次我們扮演的是異形，作戰方式幾乎都是近距離搏鬥，沒有強大的遠程火力可用，因此任何持槍的敵人都是嚴重威脅，在戰鬥上會更貼近偷偷來的模式，利用陷阱、製造聲響干擾敵人，在透過通風道偷偷繞行到敵人後方攻擊，這一點會讓策略部分的玩法比較不一樣。

[b]真正的透過殺死敵人，來壯大自己！[/b]
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1680962344

[h1]80年代的黑色幽默喜劇[/h1]
遊戲在美術用色、劇情上，很有80年代科幻電影的風格，故事講述一間貪婪的能源企業，駕駛一艘巨型太空船降臨一顆充滿異形的星球，在降落的過程中壓死了許多異形，並想掏空這座星球的資源，而異形蟲后則潛入這座太空船展開報復，以往這種劇情的電影我們都是透過人類的視角來觀看，這次則可以由異形的角度來欣賞，不過結論都是人類因為太好奇或貪婪，活該招惹異形啦！

[b]劇情非常搞笑，充滿各種黑色幽默[/b]
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1696501466

[h1]遊戲優缺點[/h1]

✔️ 扮演異形，體驗吞噬、生產、演化的力量。
✔️ 80年代電影的黑色幽默風格。
✔️ 不一樣的策略玩法。
✔️ 美術風格不錯。

❌ 兵種單位種類少。
❌ 關卡數量太少，僅7關。
❌ 戰鬥偏潛行向，節奏較慢。

[b]戰鬥更偏向潛行、偷襲，很難正面硬上[/b]
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1680962610

[h1]結論[/h1]
遊戲不論在玩法、題材與創意上都有自己的特色，唯獨就是內容不夠多，戰役只有7個關卡，讓人有意猶未盡的感覺，加上異形的種類扣除蟲后就只剩下三種特殊單位，也讓戰鬥的變化少了許多，相當可惜；不過由於臺灣區定價只有美區的一半，如遇特賣時，當作一款類 XCOM 的策略小品來體驗是相當不錯的！

review:
It's a fun, light-hearted turn-based-strategy game where the enemies are humans and you, the good guys, are a hive-mind of aliens defending themselves from their invasion. The comedy is rather on point and while only two of the characters are voiced, their interactions brought a smile to my face several times. Their whacky hi-jinks and all. 

For a game like this, you get 6-7 hours worth of content via a single player campaign where you're storming up several levels of a spaceship/spacestation? and you have to use stealth to your advantage. As humans are more numerous than you and have guns, that's your only choice in this matter. Game doesn't have the best optimization but it's alright. Music is alright and so are the SFX. 

For a game like this, I was pleasently surprised by how well they did. This easily could have just been shoved out the door and they probably would have considered that good enough. Now, it is just a single player campaign with some skill trees. No multiplayer, no co-op and nothing much else. But I enjoyed my time with it and it's nice to see games know what they are and release with just enough content to be satisfying. Kudos to the devs.

review:
So what happens when you make a light version of X-Com told from the alien's point of view, mixed with a fair dash of Douglas Adams/Red Dwarf humour? A decent-ish take on the tactical squad-based genre. 
AofE is a competent enough game. The elements are all there - tiles, action points, overwatch, sightlines. If you've played X-Com or Jagged Alliance you know the drill. 
The gimmick here is you don't start with a squad. You have a single "matriarch" unit - an alien queen if you will - that spawns a basic unit. The basic units can then turn into larger units. The matriarch can pump out one unit a turn. All of this is powered by "biomass" which is a currency you get from consuming corpses.
This is wonderfully thematic, you get a Zerg or Tyranid "conquer and consume" kind of vibe that fits well with the lore. The problem is that what often works from a story perspective isn't great for a game.
It's extremely bloody slow. 
You start with one unit. It has to kill something and eat it. Then it pumps out another unit, which in turn kills and consumes. Yes exponential mathematics means that eventually you'll have enough aliens to conquer a planet, but damn does it take a long time for this snowball to start rolling. 
I'd rather start with a squad thanks. 
Attack of the Earthlings isn't a bad game. It's good enough, if not groundbreaking. And it doesn't pretend to be a AAA title - this is small time stuff and they do the job well enough. It's just that, well, X-Com 2 does it so much better. I can't think of a reason why I'd sink any more time into this when X-Com exists. 
If you want to try X-Com from the baddies perspective, with some hit-or-miss British humour, then this is your jam. If not, then there's X-Com.

"Say, Phil, ever heard of the term 'replayability'?"
"Why, yes, Joe! Yes I have! I say, bloody fantastic term, this. Posh and properly British!"
"We at Galactoil better make sure this 'replayability' item is properly implemented in our newest game."
"Why yes of course, Joe! We'll give them big companies a good show! For Queen and Country!"
"Jolly good! Just one question...what exactly -is- replayability?"
"...I haven't the slightest clue, Joe. Ooh, wait, tea time! Let's go for a spot of tea, wot wot."

...and that's how I imagined how the developers decided against putting in any form of conventional replayability into Attack of the Earthlings. No New Game+, limited character progression (3 upgrades per unit type for 3 total unit types, plus 4 upgrades for your hero unit), and the absolutely confounding idea of not letting players replay beaten levels.

Yup. For a game that has multiple achievements per level, you'll have to start a new game each time, losing all your progress, just to, say, go for the speedrun achievement. Obviously, achievements aren't mandatory, but still. Perhaps they don't want players to grind for every upgrade and have to pick and choose? I suppose that makes some achievements more challenging, but tedious at the same time.

It's a shame that the complete omission of replayability is such a deal-breaker for me, because aside from that, I genuinely enjoyed the experience (at least until finding out after beating it that I cannot carry over my progress). I can't say that the game did exceptionally well in any single regard (aside from the humor, which I adored, but definitely not for everyone), but all the pieces are serviceable, solid even, and so is the overall product. Even with the lack of replayability, I can still comfortably recommend it at $10, but $20 for a game that I cannot be asked to beat again just for the sake of achievements is a bit too much.

review:
A casually tactical diversion that doesn't overstay its welcome.

Pros: 
- Tight design space, a nice change of pace from other entries in the genre.
- Well made, with no bugs found, clear tooltips and visual design that is both pretty and readable.
- Occasionally funny.

Cons:
- Edginess. The annoying kind. I'm guessing that I don't need to say this, most people probably saw the black and red player character designs and correctly guessed that the story would embarrass itself a bit...
- The research level. Politely, it could be called experimental but it would be more honest to call it a mistake. It's over eventually.
- Bad jokes mean no replay value. They're not all winners and I can't imagine putting up with some of these lines twice. At least the voice acting is fine.

Overall, a decent game, far from spectacular but it does the important things right more often than some triple-A studios. It's a solid day's worth of diversion, only challenging once in a while but satisfying nonetheless. I recommend playing towards fastest mission clear possible for the most enjoyable experience.

review:
While the idea, trailers and screen shots look great this is simply clever marketing. This game is very shallow and annoying. 

The game is about 6-8 hours long and a total of 7 missions with no replayability. All the enemies and events are scripted and follow the exact same pathing every time. On top of this you can't replay levels you finish. They make you START THE GAME AGAIN FROM SCRATCH. If you plan on getting this regardless make a seperate hard save file before starting each mission. 

The art style is the only props I'll give to this game. It looks great. 

The enemies make dumb noises, the humor is weak at best and the music gets old fast. 

Cutscenes can be skipped but there is a lot of talking (again with the weak humor) that you just have to tollerate or mute while playing. Additionally the enemy moves and turns take ages with no way to skip. 

The UI is a lot bigger than it needs to be and camera angles are poor and move constantly. 

Overall this is a $5-10 game at best for one quick play through and not worth anything near the current price.

author: {'steamid': '76561197973811733', 'num_games_owned': 573, 'num_reviews': 82, 'playtime_forever': 182, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 146, 'last_played': 1558917547}
review:
[h1]MOCX[/h1]

Okay, maybe it might not be best to call it that, though at first glance, it certainly gives off that impression of being a reverse XCOM, since you play as what can best be described as a copyright-neutral version of the Alien Queen: The Matriarch.

As the Matriarch, your goal is to sneak into a massive drill/corporate office and generally murder everything in sight... stealthily of course, because as we all know, bug-like aliens without any sort of firearm are pretty vulnerable to bullets. As in (die in one hit) sort of vulnerable. Fortunately, you have a lot of special abilities that can level the playing field!

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

Due to the high lethality in this game, you're gonna approach the humans stealthily, with your basic grunts utilizing vents to avoid enemy patrols while also eating the corpses you leave behind to collect biomass. At the first mission, it's really only used to create more grunts, though you are encouraged to not throw them into suicidal situations as you get penalized through fewer upgrade points that are introduced in the second mission (at that point, you unlock the full extent of what the alien arsenal has to offer

The grunt, while not having sort of upgrades, still provides a level of utility since it can crawl through vents as I have previously mentioned. Not only are they a hiding spot, but they also allow you to teleport to connected vents, which can prove quite effective when bypassing (and possibly murdering) enemy patrols, and dead people means more biomass. More biomass means evolutions (Goliath/Disruptor/Stalker).

The Goliath as the name implies, is a pretty big guy, being able to take TWO bullets to the face instead of one. From my personal experience, he seems to be a pretty decent pick if you're expecting to be put into a situation where you absolutely have to tank damage, and has the ability to increase his armor at the expense of the current turn's attack action. He also deals additional damage, which can prove handy when attempting to one-shot the tougher security guards.

The Disrupter is your ranged unit, and while their spit has a two-turn cooldown, is still a very important aspect as they still have a longer range than the security guard's vision cone, so you can probably expect to use him a lot in larger rooms where you have that level of maneuverability.

And finally, the Stalker. Essentially a stronger version of the Grunt, he can still crawl through vents and ignore armor with his melee attack. He can also be upgraded to deal backstab damage, which i'm expecting to be extremely useful in the later levels (Have only played through the first two missions, tutorial excluded)

Well... Okay, i say finally, but one ability that's shared with all the aliens is the Group attack, where you queue up multiple attack actions on the same unit, and press a big red button to overwhelm that health sponge before he can shoot back at you.

The execution is well... I really only have two complaints about Attack of the Earthlings: the game's length. Those complaints are...

[h1] The game's length[/h1]
 As soon as you finish the first mission, you get a mission select screen which reveals the full length of the game: 7 missions. I dunno how such a thing would be implemented, though I can't help but think there needs to be some form of procedural generation so that if you DO replay older missions, you're never gonna see the same layout as you did the first time you played it.  Onto the second complaint

[h1]Voice acting[/h1]
During the game's cutscenes where you're not looking through an overhead perspective, it seems kind of odd to do textboxes instead of voiced dialogue. So far, i've only seen generic workers in these scenes and I think it'd be good to have the devs do the voice actors since well... you don't need famous voice actors to do your regular joe shmoe.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
There's very few bad things I can say about this game since it does the whole "alien perspective" thing very well and for the bad things I can say about the game... It isn't exactly worth a thumbs down, but it is worth putting yourself on a discount waitlist such as IsThereAnyDeal or just simply adding the game to your Wishlist in preparations for the Steam CHRISTMAS SALE.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998055962', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1697, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 568, 'last_played': 1575456564}
review:
Fun, enjoyable game that I wish there was more of. The foundations are there for a really great game, but there's a lot of aspects that feel they could be expanded on. In no particular order:

1. There's only 7 levels. The levels and objectives were fun, and there's a lot of strategy and careful patients that needs to be employed at times. But it's over far too soon. I was hoping for either a second world/location, or some bonus levels after the campaign was done. Unfortunately there's neither of these, and while the levels were enjoyable, I find little replayability in them. I would have loved to have seen more environments, especially with the setting/theme of the game.

2. There's only 5 units. The Matriarch acts as a moving base, able to attack and spawn basic units (Grunts) on the go. The Grunts she spawns can be evolved into 1 of 3 different units: a 'tanky' Goliath, a 'ranged' Disruptor, and a 'stealthy' Stalker. The reasons for the quotes is these units feel like they have the bare essentials to be considered those classes. The Goliath initially seems cool, with the ability to make themselves slightly tankier, dealing more base damage, and the only unit with an AoE attack, but there's rarely an occasion where he feels needed after you initially get him, and the AoE seems pointless as I can't think of an instance where 2 enemies were actually next to each other. I stopped using him all together after level 

3. The Disruptor has ranged abilities, but its basic attack is still melee ranged. This starts to feel extremely clunky, as only one of the abilities actually deals damage and it has a 2 turn cooldown. I only used these when I absolutely had to. The Stalker is easily the best pick, and I often found myself just creating an army of theses and eliminating everything I came across. They're the cheapest to evolve in to, they have the best mobility, and end up being your best source of damage if played right. It would have been great to see more variety and balanced design.

3. Each unit only has 3 upgrades. At the end of levels you earn points for a number of things (turns it took to complete the level, if you completed side objectives etc), and those points can be used to upgrade your units and unlock new abilities. And given that the Grunt cannot be upgraded, it amounts to a total of 12 potential upgrades. But as mentioned previously, the Stalker is the only unit that these upgrades feel worthwhile. It wouldn't have been hard to earn enough points to unlock all potential upgrades, but after fully upgrading the Stalker to be even better than it initially was I didn't bother. The concept honestly feels like an afterthought as a means to incentivise replay, however given I already wasn't using one of the units and barely using the other, it failed in this regard.

4. Plot is simple, but works. I found the humour hit the right levels of silly without getting stupid and annoying. There were some bits where I genuinely chuckled at a good line or moment. I would have liked to see more characters, but with only 7 levels it's understandable why the plot essentially revolves around 2 bickering protagonists. 

Despite all of my criticisms, all in all I quite enjoyed the experience, I just REALLY wish there was more of it.

review:
Очень забавная пародия на X-COM, но наоборот. Людишки прилетели порабощать нашу планету. А мы, в роли Свормеров, отправляемся в путешествие дабы раздать им галактических звездюлей. Быстро, задорно и весело.

review:
Attack of the Earthlings is a turn-based strategy game. You control a couple of residents from the local planet where a human mining organisation is busy bleeding the planet dry. You, a matriarch, find your way into this giant space mining drill and make your way to the boss of this operation.

The level design is done nicely, and each level can be played in multiple ways. It's somewhat easy to finish each level, but the game has achievements for some ways to play each level that is a lot harder. After beating the game once, you'll likely want to see if you can win the game with different, or even no upgrades. My first playthrough was about 10 hours long.

I found the music in the game somewhat repetitive, but the voice-acting is great. The cutscenes are nicely done and made me chuckle more than once.

I would wholeheartedly recommend to pick this game up.

review:
Attack of the Earthlings is a Turn-based Strategy similar to XCOM with a strong stealth focus. The game tends not to take itself seriously which often works to its favor.  

Pros
•	Attack of the Earthlings’ overall humorous tone and homages to classic Sci-fi movies makes it quite enjoyable. 
•	Decent sound track and the ambient noise helps to fill dead space while planning out a turn.
•	This game takes a while to Finish, about 8-15 hours depending on speed. (I’m a good quarter of the way though the game at 2.4 hours in.)

Cons
•	The humor can be hit or miss at times.
•	Low to nonexistent replayability.
•	Price is a bit steep for the play time
Neither
•	The story is so-so some people will like it for the comedic aspects and some will hate it but as far as stories go it’s pretty simplistic.
•	The art style is A bit cartoonish for me, But that’s more of a personal preference.
Overall, I’d recommend getting this game if you don't mind dark humor and space aliens when it’s on sale or drops in price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027250444', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 86, 'playtime_forever': 585, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 585, 'last_played': 1525363513}
review:
This is a very charming game. It's about a conflict between space explorers and horrible aliens - but you get to be the aliens this time! You go through a spaceship that landed on your planet level by level and gradually eradicate the human crew that came to exploit your homeworld! 

You start each level as an alien queen (called the Matriarch) and the number of additional aliens you can spawn depend on how many people (enemies) you are able to kill and devour, using the biomass gained from corpses as a resource for building your squad on the go. 

The turn-based combat is not very complicated but it's fun and it offers a few interesting tactical choices with your units - you can evolve your basic grunts into different units that are more powerful in different areas (brute force, ranged attacks, backstabbing). 

Each level is different and has various objectives, it all ties to the story that is actually very funny - this game is also a comedy with plentiful hilarious moments! 

Yes the game coud be longer, but it's still worth it. Fun combat and fun story, good game overall.

author: {'steamid': '76561198087813151', 'num_games_owned': 5538, 'num_reviews': 256, 'playtime_forever': 379, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 379, 'last_played': 1524250992}
review:
Attack of the Earthlings

Let me start by saying this game is very funny.
Its a turnbased strategy game with a lot of (dark) humour.
The story is actually the upside down version of XCOM. This time the humans have invaded your planet. You play as an alien to get rid of those nasty humans and save your planet.

The game doesn't really play like XCOM. You have at the beginning of a turn AP (around 8) you can use this AP any way you like: every step costs 1 AP, fighting costs AP, eating the bodies costs AP, etc
The Matriarch is the most important creature, if she dies it is game over. She uses biomass to spawn Grunt offspring. You earn biomass by killing humans and by eating bodies (humans and aliens)
Your Grunts can be upgraded in different creatures.
Also you can mindcontrol 1 human at a time to trick other humans.

The graphics are very good. The cutscenes are hilarious. The music is good. Only the voiceacting could be a little more extensive.

There are no difficulty settings, which is not a good thing. There is little replayability this way.

In total there are 7 levels. I have played the first 3 levels upon writing this review. The levels are big. Of course you could rush through the levels like some people like to do, but if you want to complete all objectives in a level including the optional ones the game has a fair length for its price.

There is a very good tutorial that takes you by the hand, so you can learn every new feature.
I wish all games used a tutorial like this game. 


I think €22.99 (base price) is a bit to steep for some people, but in my opinion it is worth the price.
I would give this one an 8.5 out of 10. Really enjoyed this strategy game.

review:
船上で怪物と追いかけっこするゲーム『Monstrum』のメーカーが作った、エイリアンになって人類をおやつにするゲーム。エイリアンというのはいわゆる映画の黒くてデカくて頭が長い、ダクトとか通って人を襲うアレみたいな感じです。アレになるゲーム。そういうのが好き、洋ゲーの雰囲気がハダに合う人にはオススメです。充分なローカライズもされてるので遊ぶのに難は無いです。

ただシミュレーションとしては簡単な部類だと思います。STRやらDEXなどのユニット毎のステータスは無いですし、距離や角度などでの攻撃命中率変化も無い。難易度ベリーハードとかゲーム中セーブ不可などのドM向けのエグイオプションもありません。エイリアンらしくあんまり頭を使わずに、最終的に数で圧倒すればイケルイケルというような、ゆるく楽しめる難易度のゲームです。戦略シミュレーションガチ勢には物足りない内容かもしれませんね。

ただですね、このゲーム　いま追加コンテンツを製作中だそうで、ステージや難易度が追加される可能性が出てます。(実施しているアンケートにそういう欄がある。) なのでウィッシュリストに入れといて、開発のtwitter(@TeamJunkfish)フォローしといて、なんか動きがあってそれ見て買う気になったらセールの時に買うってのがいいと思います。僕も注目してるんで、なんかあったらここにまた書くんで、まあよかったらどうぞ。開発がtwitterで「やったわ！"非常に好評"なったわ！」って喜んでました。嬉しそうでした。

Le gameplay allie le tour par tour traditionnel avec un système d'infiltration, l'IA des ennemis n'a rien de particulier mais reste correct.
Les graphismes sont plutot bon, vous trouverez également des petits détails dans le design des niveaux qui sont cool et qui je pense apporte beaucoup à l'ambiance du jeu.

Points Négatifs: Je n'ai pas encore finit le jeu mais à la vitesse où l'on avance j'ai peur que le jeu soit très court. Comme je le disais précedement on est en présence d'une bonne IA mais sans réelle difficultée.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014902234', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 446, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 446, 'last_played': 1519329654}
review:
It may be a yes, but it has a caveat or two.

I found this game easy; not sure whether it was the settings or whether it was intentional, I chewed through the game.  Once you know the objective, you can quickly finish the levels quickly.

The enemies are a double edged sword; unlike invisible Inc you can't brute force them as they need to be taken out in one shot otherwise you will lose units, no recovery.  High health can only be taken out by the brute, fast melee at range, armoured units taken out by the stealth units.

The problem is they make monty python's holy grail knights look competant; they fail to communicate, the pattern to take them down is painfully easy and they wall hug everywhere meaning overwatch abuse is constant.

Secondly, killing enemies allows you to eat them and buy more units meaning you can have a large number of units and losing a unit (except the leader) is just a road bump unlike Invisible Inc which makes every mistake requiring a change of plan very quickly to get back on track.  At one point I had enough resourcces to rebuild a large force twice over.

Thirdly, while there are some changes during the missions; they are not enough to change the challenge.  There is no time pressure; now I know that the Security Level was contraversial in Invisible Inc, but time pressure was required to make you feel like a skilled thief.  While you have the post mission loop, it just doesn't feel enough, apart from one or two buffs, the incentive to level up units is not there, you probably could complete all the game with the base units.

So while I recommend it for the laughs and tropes it works off and the idea of reverse Xcom.  If you need the challenge, Invisible Inc wins out.

review:
Очень хорошая пошаговая стратегия с оригинальным сеттингом и идеей.

Из достоинств можно отметить: 
1) Хороший баланс. Каждый юнит пришельцев полезен в бою и обладает способностями позволяющими, при должном умении, выкарабкиваться из самых неприятных ситуаций. Вражеские юниты требуют индивидуального подхода к их истреблению, и обладают очень неприятными особенностями.
2) Отсутствие RNGesus'а (рандома), значения урона фиксированы. 
3) Интересные уровни. Хоть их и не много, сделаны они на отлично. Каждый уровень проходится по-разному, требуя от игрока выполнения определенных действий (заданий).
4) Юмор. Диалоги персонажей, каламбуры и просто происходящее на экране.

Главный минус этой игры - количество контента. Она очень коротка (7 миссий). Видов врагов, пришельцев, способностей не так уж и много. Ровно столько сколько нужно на эти семь миссий и не больше.

Свои 460 рублей она однозначно стоит, очень хорошая игра за свои деньги. Если будет скидка - еще лучше.

review:
Above all else I had a lot of fun with this game, despite a couple of nitpicks.

Quite a few of people have compared this to Invisible Inc. as well as XCOM but I think that where the game stands out from these is how the Biomass mechanic causes each mission to develop: it pays to be stealthy early on, when there's few of you, but each unit you can produce gradually increases your tactical options, gradually favouring more aggressive behaviour until even a dense group of enemies has no hope of stopping your onslaught!

Creativity with your units is also a major asset; I rarely felt the need to play it safe as I do in XCOM and Invisible Inc. The upgrades to your units can seem a little too powerful sometimes, but the real trick is chaining them with one another; when combined with good positioning this will allow you to handle every situation the game can throw at you.

The comedy occassionally went over my homicidal insectoid head, but attention to detail is where the game really shines here, keep your eyes peeled at all times!

A novel experience in tactical games for me. I only wish there was a hard mode!

Recht lustig gemacht. Die Aliens sind im ggs. zum mühsam aufgelevelten X-Com Soldaten völlig entbehrlich. Das Spiel ist relativ einfach, da man durch Türen und Wände sehen kann, wenn man dichter ran geht. Somit ein recht entspanntes, amüsantes Stratgie-
 bzw. Puzzelspiel. Leider etwas sehr kurz geraten für den Preis. In lt. Anzeige 12h war ich durch inkl. mindestens eine Stunde afk und trotz Zeit-lassen. Wiederspielwert sehe ich ehrlich gesagt keinen und ein Ausprobieren von verschiedenen Strategien ist zwar angedacht, kommt aber aufgrund der Spielmechanik nicht zu zum tragen. Im wesentlichen kann man 3 von 4 Ästen im Skillbaum fokussieren, 3 Äste fallen auf die 3 Alien-Typen, der 4. auf die "Mutter", die als einzige nicht sterben darf. Da man die Spucklinge aber nicht braucht (Fernkämpfer) fehlt nichts, wenn in deren Fähigkeiten keine Punkte steckt. Damit haben sich die strategischen Möglichkeiten auch schon erschöpft. review:
【配图版本请参见[url=https://cowlevel.net/game/Attack_of_the_Earthlings/review/3019283]奶牛关[/url]】

在过去的不少策略游戏里，外星人往往是那个强势的一方，登陆地球，无恶不作，而奋起反抗的英雄人类一般都是主角，不知不觉，这似乎已经成为了一种正统，以一敌百的机枪勇士，脆弱但是群体出击的虫群和外星人，这些形象太过经典，也偶尔会让人觉得审美疲劳。

但在这款别具一格的《地球人侵袭》里，你操控的角色却是被夺走了家乡的虫母，一个人类的采掘公司占据了你的家，这使得我们的主角不得不奋起反击。如何潜入人类复杂的安保系统，夺回属于你的星球，成为了这款潜入策略游戏的主题。

游戏中，我们的虫后不仅拥有强悍的战斗能力，最重要的是，她有随时生产的能力。孤身一人想要挑战几十个安保守卫确实太过困难，但在吞噬了敌人的尸体获得了生物质之后，她就能创造出新的幼虫，并把他们变成巨兽，干扰者，追击者三种不同的兵种，发挥他们的优势，打败强大的敌人。

而游戏中的反派，当然就是那些腐朽昏庸的人类了。加拉托利能源公司显然是一家唯利益论的公司，游戏中，除了钱和小木马什么也不爱的老板迪克汉姆，和奸诈狡猾的管理员派克，在配音演员生动的呈现下都显得相当有趣，有一瞬间让我想起了同样侧重于搞笑情节的一款优质游戏《死亡怪兽塔》。其实员工们的对话也相当搞笑，但制作组显然在那些地方请不起配音了（。

略显可惜的是，游戏虽然在这个虫群的创意和反派配音，搞笑文案层面下足了工夫（机器人在我玩完整个游戏的时间里没看到过几次重复的段子，每一关都有比较有意思的情节和对白），策略游戏的部分却非常的苍白。

《地球人侵袭》在目前的版本里总共有七个关卡，每关虽然目标各有不同，有生存战，也有歼灭特定目标的战斗，但战术的思路大体相同，都是利用敌方看不到我方的视野优势，用先攻的优势尽可能无伤的击败对方。

游戏的血量设计明显没有给策略多少容错空间，游戏中守卫的视野是否能穿越某个物品也没有完全统一，经常出现差一步守住结果提前被打到的尴尬情况，这些小问题也给游戏的体验节奏埋下了隐患。一旦玩家策略上存在一个小的失误，原本被玩家控制的视野和防御范围很容易陷入崩溃的局面。还好游戏的自动存档做的比较充足，虽然游戏比较容易陷入需要SL试错的层面，但对游戏体验的打断没有那么严重。对游戏体验打断更严重的，可能是过一个回合时N次镜头位移带来的不必要的时间浪费。

战略层方面，《地球人侵袭》也可以说是“战略性”放弃，由于游戏体量的问题，游戏只剩下了四种兵种（包括虫后）各三个升级，且完全是线性，这也使得游戏的升级只是抉择侧重于哪个兵种，而游戏每一关的敌人配置又决定了你几乎肯定要同时使用这三种兵种，再加上完全没必要的不统一的升级费用，使得升级的目的变得有点混乱。

策略游戏部分的平庸，和“生活质量”类小设计的缺失，让游戏的体验变得有点让人焦躁，但还好有趣的点不算太少，总的来说，会是一款打折期间值得一玩的游戏，如果你是冲着游戏独特的策略视角来玩的话，还是回去玩更成熟的Invisible,Inc吧。

author: {'steamid': '76561198041585700', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1029, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 472, 'last_played': 1572185582}
review:
Probably decent fun for fans of XCOMish games, however there are some flaws one should take into consideration before buying.

Pros:
+ Setting: Ever wanted to fight a (cartoonishly) evil & incompetent megacorp invading your planet as an Alien/Zerg inspired queen that loves to devour anything in her way? Look no further!
+ Humour: This game doesn't take itself too seriously, really liked the dark humour in this. Never thought I'd ever laugh about a depressed defense turret.
+ Combat: Really rather but still fun, not many units but being able to level up your minions/queen keeps it fresh
+ Map design: The story is really quite basic (you are fighting your way up a giant mining drill ship) to kill the "baddies" but a lot of love was put into the maps and little details, most levels also have a side objective that adds to the feeling
+ Sound/Music: Nice sound design and music (although the latter is a bit repetitive), only the two main antagonists have proper voice actors but they carry the story well.

Cons:
- Content: I beat this game in 8 hours, as of this review there is no content besides the campaign. One should ask themselves whether a well crafted but short game like this is worth 20 bucks before buying.
- No difficulty settings: This game is really not too challenging, especially if you focus on units that perform very well (imo  a bunch of OP leveled Stalkers with Disruptor support can handle anything thrown at them rather easily). People that like a big challenge and know turn based strategy games could get bored. It doesn't help that the enemy AI is extremely simple and therefore easy to predict.
- Questionable replayabilty value: One can always replay the story but I don't really see much extra worth in doing that. Sure you could try to improve your score, beat missions as fast as possible and such but for many people this game will probably something they'll maybe play through once.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000674674', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 497, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 497, 'last_played': 1518419580}
review:
Imagine if you played as the Insect Aliens from XCOM, but instead of fighting a global taskforce, you fight the company from the IT Crowd -  in space. This is a tactical stealth game with a heavy focus on using the different abilities of your aliens to kill and consume humans, working your way up until you can put a stop to the human invaders. The game is pretty heavy on comedy, but luckily it's almost all situational comedy about how inept the megacorp is and works rather well, especially in the later half of the game. Maybe not hilarious, but certainly makes you smile.

The gameplay boils down to a stealth-focused turn based strategy game, like Invisible Inc. There's a mother alien, Matriarch, that can spawn Drones, which differentiate into 3 distinct classes: Goliaths which are like tanky bruisers, Disrupters which are ranged specialists with blinding, and Stalkers which are trap-laying, backstabbers. At first the classes all seem distinct and very useful but the game becomes far too easy with the Stalker - which can make enemies unable to attack, get extra actions, and even deal the highest damage in the game short of a fully upgraded Matriarch.

The upgrade system is rather good though; you get score for completing levels which directly translates to upgrade points for either your Matriarch or the specialist classes. The upgrades apply to all aliens you spawn and can be easily swapped out between missions, as you don't "buy" upgrades so much as just select a loadout. In theory this could make some interesting remixes of missions; selecting abilities to counter threats, but you don't know what an upcoming level will have and there are too few upgrades to really specialise. Luckily the upgrades they do have are quite good and can really let you breeze through some levels - almost too easily at points. The last two levels have something resembling 'boss fights' that are a little too easy - especially if you take fully upgraded Stalkers.

However, I do recommend trying this game if you can afford it. The levels are creative, the gameplay is fun, and the story can be quite funny. I purchased this game at 10% off, at around $23USD, although I think 25 is a good price for it, and completed the game in about 8 hours. I think there's about 8 missions, so it's a decent length for what it is.

review:
プレイ時間：8.3時間(クリア済み)
公式日本語化：あり(ただし一部イベント訳もれ/進行に支障はない)
難易度設定：なし

[h1]異星に地球人が侵略してきた！　子供らを引き連れて悪徳大企業の手から星を救うのだ！[/h1]
というノリで始まる本作だが、一見Xcomライク、その実面クリア型ステルス主体のゲームである。
パワードスーツと銃器で武装した人間たちはエイリアンより圧倒的に強く、狂信的で、そのうえ間抜けだ。
もしあなたがエイリアンを操ってド派手な復讐劇を繰り広げたいと思うのなら。あるいは、エイリアンの軍隊を強化して戦術的に母星を開放したいと考えるのなら。
[b]……このゲームを選ぶべきではないだろう[/b]。


そうではなく、物陰に隠れて間抜けにも一人で哨戒していた地球人を引きずり込んだり、換気口から突如として現れてみたり、地球人に寄生して誕生日パーティをぶち壊しにしたいと思ったなら、このゲームは値段相応におすすめだということになる。
発見即射殺に近い難易度ではあるが、ステージ中時間制限などはほぼなく、クリアターン数もステージクリア評価に関わるだけなので、じっくり敵の巡回を確認しながら進めば決して難しくはない。
また、5ターン毎オートセーブ機能に加え、ステージ中でも任意セーブができるため、死んで覚えるスタイルもありといえばありだろう。
ステージ数は全部で7つ。すべて違うギミックが組み込まれているので飽きは来ないが、やりこみ要素も前述のクリア評価だけなので、物足りなさは覚える。


エイリアンには母体となる主人公、すべてのエイリアンの成長元となる幼体を除いて三種類の変化先が存在する。
変化も含め、各ステージの最初には母体しか操作することができず、ステージ内で稼いだポイントを消費して増員、あるいは強化していくこととなる。
引き継がれるアップグレードは各ステージのクリア後にもらえる評価を消費して獲得できるが、かならず取得する共通のものが1つ、あとは母体と変化先ごとに各3つずつという少し悲しい数しかない。
前のステージに戻ってプレイすることができないため、すべてアップグレードするのは難しい。


レビュー現在（2018/02/12時点）クリア後データの作成などがなく、最終ステージに入る前にセーブしたデータを上書きしてしまった場合、これまでのスコアの確認などが非常にめんどくさい。
念のため、各ステージからインターミッションに戻るには、Escメニュー→「終了」→「キャンペーン」でステージ突入前に戻ることができる。これでスコアの確認も安心だ。
[strike] 最終ステージ？　ラスボスにとどめを刺す直前にセーブでもするかスクリーンショットでも撮ればいいんじゃない？[/strike] 　
アップデートに期待しましょう。

author: {'steamid': '76561197990352502', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 660, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 660, 'last_played': 1518357554}
review:
This was surprisingly good. A nice idea very competently executed.
Although everyone and their dog will likely compare this to X-COM it is actually a lot more like Invisible Inc. except killing your enemies is important here.
You control a group of insectoid aliens trying to exterminate the pesky humans who have invaded your planet with a huge drill. There are seven levels and you begin each one with your main unit the matriarch who is able to spawn more using biomass which you get from defeated humans.

This is without doubt the best aspect of the game. You really feel like you are controlling an alien swarm, creeping through the enemy base, picking off guards one by one and constantly growing in strength and numbers until you become an unstoppable force. Humans have superior firepower and the home turf advantage so you must use ambush tactics and strategy to prevail.

The core mechanics are solid, the turn based system is done well (which is rare in indie titles IMO). It looks a bit simple at first but has a surprising strategical depth. There aren't a lot of units or upgrades but they are all viable and necessary, there is nothing so overpowered to outshine all the other options nor is there anything so underwhelming that you never want to use it.

Graphics and sounds are good enough. They are nothing spectacular but there are no glaring flaws either. Maybe some of the animations are a bit clunky but it's a minor issue.

If you are a veteran of the genre you will likely find the game a little too easy but because your enemies powerful throughout the game it never gets to the point where you can just send in your overpowered units and win, you always have to use your head.

It's a bit short, the seven levels provide about 7-8 hours of pure game (not counting reloading and trying to get some of the achievements).

I left the humor for the last. It is...there. The corporation you are trying to take out is cartoonishly greedy, evil and incompetent. I liked some of the more subtle quips like the little tweets you can read on the displays and a few scenes you run into in the game but the "funny banter" between the two main antagonists (the protagonist does not speak) was overdone. Yeah, I get it, the boss is incompetent, no need to hammer the fact home by the 54th hilariously funny little scene.

Overall this is a very nice little gem that made my weekend. If you like turn based strategy and the premise interests you there is no reason not to pick this up. If only one of those two is true...well you can wait for a sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971326962', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 529, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 529, 'last_played': 1518280299}
review:
Summary -
You'll probably love this if : You like turn based tactical combat games.
You'll hate this if you think : Turn based games suck. Stealthy approaches are tedious. You need strategic dynamic campaigns for your tactical warfare ( XCOM, Total War Series etc )

The Good : Solid turn based tactical game.
The Not So Good : Short. Very little to zero replayability. 25$ Price point vs Content. If you're conservative with your gaming dollar, you might want to hold off.

Detail -
Attack of the Earthlings is a solid, if simple, turn based tactical combat game in the style of XCOM, where the roles are reversed from the common setup and you get to play the Aliens fighting off the "evil" invading Earthlings. Unlike XCOM the game is purely a tactical combat simulator and nothing else - there is no strategic level of bases, logistics and management. The tone of the game is one of cariacture comedy, particularly British comedy , no surprise given the team is based in Scotland. But don't expect any grim dark horror vibes creeping in that some Alien attack tropes bring to the table.

As the Aliens you are mostly a stealth based melee force pitted against a mostly non stealth based range force. So the typical trope for this kind of setup. Claws v Guns ! There are a handful of different units and capabilities on each side - just enough to give you something to think about - which means there is some flexibility in approach for you as a player.

The game itself plays out as a linear campaign of several static maps on which to fight following a progressive story of your journey to the very top of the Earthlings ship/drilling rig. As a result the game follows a scripted narrative path, with voice acting filling in the cut scene moments that progress the story. 

Overall the quality of the game has the feel of a good indie production - you're not going to see AAA levels of polish and FX here, but the game is solid and has more of a pro lo-fi quality about it. There are a few bugs and annoyances in game, but I've not experience anything that's more than a minor inconvenience, so QA seems pretty good. All in all, an enjoyable turn based tactical sim - but with one caveat.

The caveat is game length ( and replability ). I didn't rush the game and completed it in just under 8 hours. At its release price and indie quality level this feels to me somewhat short. Closely related to the game length is the issue of replayability. Despite being a tactical turn based sim, the game has next to zero replayability because you're playing through a scripted narrative short campaign where each mission you start anew, with your single unit. The story is always the same, and there are no ( or almost no ) consequences that carry over from prior missions. This feels like a bit of a missed opportunity by the devs to either change the campaign a bit to be more dynamic and have some level of strategic gameplay, or, failing that, add in a procedural mission creator / campaign generator to significantly bump up play time and replayability. Multiplayer for this would also be a great benefit here, a versus or co-op mode on procedural maps would transform the game experience, whilst from a dev persective re-using a lot of the work that's already gone into the game production.

On balance, I think the game with its scripted linear format needed a much longer campaign - double the length. Or failing that needed to add some dynamic replayability to the mix.

Overall a recommendation - but, given the amount of content and price point, if you are conservative with your gaming dollar you may want to look elsewhere.

review:
A lot of reviews have been comparing AotE to XCOM, but other than art style, the turn-based combat, and the fact that there are aliens in it, I just don't see the comparison.  Some major differences:

1. No RNG.  If you attack (or are attacked), you deal (or take) a flat amount of damage.  This means that AotE doesn't ever feel unfair, but it also means that it doesn't have those bullet-sweating moments where you pull through by sheer luck.

2. A real AP pool.  The attack actions are still separate from standard AP, but you don't just have one movement and one attack (and you can always move after an attack).

3. Focused on stealth and close combat.  You get some ranged attacks, but most of the focus is on getting in close without alerting the enemy.

4. The campaign is made up of pre-built missions.  You're not managing a campaign to fend off earthlings, like you are in XCOM; in AotE, you're just ascending the levels of one ship and trying to get rid of them.

To me, the gameplay feels more like Shadowrun than XCOM.  It was still very satisfying, though, and the lack of RNG just kept me from getting angry at the game.

My biggest complaint is that there's not really much to do after the campaign.  I could go back and try to improve my score on previous levels, but that's about all.  I wish there were procedurally generated levels just so I could keep playing the game.  The holy grail would be an XCOM-like campaign where you manage a team and have to repel multiple ships; but even just being able to generate and play through individual levels (preferably with a seed to share with friends) would give me some more humans to kill after the campaign is over.

The other main complaint that I have is that there isn't really a difficulty setting.  I'd appreciate even having a slider for enemy vision cone range, so I could increase/decrease the challenge for myself.  Part of the reason that I want to keep playing is that you can fly through the game at a breakneck pace if you learn to abuse enemies' poor vision.  A longer vision cone would force me to play a lot less aggressively.

Overall, though, I had a blast.

author: {'steamid': '76561198053788131', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 352, 'playtime_forever': 531, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 531, 'last_played': 1518084785}
review:
[h1]Introduction[/h1]
Attack of the Earthlings is a humorous turn-based strategy game from indie developers, Team Junkfish, of Monstrum fame.

Attack of the Earthlings tells the story of an interstellar space ship, one of many in the greedy Galactoil corporation's fleet, which lands on an alien planet and begins drilling for rare minerals and resources at a tremendous rate, uncaring of the effects on the planet's indigenous inhabitants.

Unknown to the Galactoil corporate lackeys on board the ship, the Matriarch, an alien with powerful and dangerous abilities, witnesses the ship's landing, and wanton destruction of many of her species in the process, and decides to do something about it -- violently.

You play the Matriarch, an angry alien on a mission of vengeance against the human incursion.

[h1]Presentation[/h1]
First impressions are good: an attractive, if slightly retro-looking, title screen with music reminiscent of a spooky circus, almost like something from Ghostbusters. Menus are well skinned and easy to use and everything fits well together. Upon starting a new game, the introductory cut scene maintains the high production values; it's in cartoon format with only basic, animations, but it's well done and sets the scene well.

The game is rendered in full 3D, but only permits camera rotation by 90 degrees, which is a bit of a shame. At least the zoom range is good, though for tactical play you'll spend most of the time zoomed out anyway. I found key-based camera panning to be way too sensitive when I first started playing, but at some point that dislike evaporated; I have no problem with it now. Graphics have a good feel to them, consistent with the title screen image, though the levels do feel a little bit 'samey' after a while; some different textures and assets wouldn't go amiss, though I should say that the current presentation does provide a consistent portrayal of the Galactoil ship.

Character models are good -- though perhaps not enough variation in civilians in particular -- and animations are convincing. The game doesn't quite manage to promote a feeling of kinship with the Matriarch and her progeny, but they're more likeable than their human prey, in any case. Apart from the opening animation, the remaining cut scenes are all scripted in game.

The interface is intuitive and easy to use, though I did initially get a bit mixed up with when to press the left mouse button instead of the right. There is a few grammatical errors, such as "it's" instead of "its", semicolons instead of colons, and missing commas, but overall the writing is pretty good. I also noticed a graphical glitch with the floor tiles occasionally drawn on top of the flamethrower flames.

Sound-wise, the music is quirky and spooky, as mentioned. Sound effects are great, with grunts, screams, squishy noises, and various weapons, though they do sound a bit isolated in cases, as if they were recorded separately and then pasted in (which is of course exactly what was done). The game is only partially voiced, with Pecker in particular warranting a mention -- he's brilliant -- but much of the script from other characters is only text, with grunting noises over the top. That said, it's still nicely done.

There are plenty of display options so if you have any problems running with everything turned up to full there's lots of room to optimise performance. I didn't have any issues running everything at maximum at 1920x1080 on a GTX 1070.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Attack of the Earthlings is a turn-based strategy game; it could be called 'squad-based', though your 'squad' on each level here comprises a single alien who can spawn others as she consumes biomass from fallen humans. Even so, the game basics are roughly the same as most other games in the genre: each of your troops has a number of points to spend on moving, attacking, and using special abilities, which you do in whatever order you desire. Once you've taken all actions for your troops you end the turn and play cycles to the enemy's turn. Line of sight, overwatch, fog of war, ... all the usual squad-based TBS components are present here and function essentially as you'd expect.

Apart from using biomass to create new 'grunts', the game also offers a few extensions to the tried-and-true formula. First, you can also use biomass to upgrade your grunts to one of the three upgradeable types: ranged, stealth, or tank. Each has its own special abilities. Attacking an enemy -- or even encountering a human or opening a door -- can produce noise that will alert other humans, prompting them to investigate. And, for taking out powerful enemies, you can synchronise attacks among multiple troops, potentially allowing you to prevent counter attacks. It's unfortunately that this only works on basic attacks, though; you can't synchronise special abilities, which reduces your tactical options significantly.

Once you enter the game proper, it offers you a brief tutorial level that allows for a couple of jokes and provides instruction in the game's basic controls and gameplay rules; for anyone familiar with the genre, there's not much to surprise you here. It's all implemented well, though -- well, mostly; pathing can be a bit stupid -- and the generous dose of humour helps to keep the game interesting.

There are seven core levels in the Galactoil ship, from the drills up to the board room. After the first couple you'll have encountered all the basic enemy types and will have all of your troops available (once you collect enough biomass), so after that it's mostly just using the same tactics over again on different maps. Each level starts you off with just the Matriarch, no matter how many units you had left on the previous one. Performance is awarded with mutagen, which you spend on troop upgrades. While I love that you can respec, it does limit replayability a bit, since you can see everything in one play. 

There are a few little niggles here and there. First, there's no map, making some of the larger levels a bit of a pain to navigate. It's not a glaring omission -- the initial fog of war is replaced by a slightly darkened rendering of the main walls and room layout of the area once you pass out of sight -- but it still would have been nice to have. I also had one crash, but it was only on exiting to desktop, so really it didn't matter at all.

I think the game's biggest weakness is its limited lifespan. With only seven levels and five troop types (four of which are upgradeable with three upgrades each), unless you're an achievement hunter you're unlikely to get more than 10 hours' play out of the game. The game tries to mix it up a bit with time/turn limits on some levels, some repetition required to learn guard routes and best paths, and a few unique enemies, which make sense in plot terms, but don't really work that well in game.

[h1]Pros and Cons[/h1]
Pros:
+ Good sense of humour
+ Unicorns. And sharks!
+ Steam Achievements

Cons:
- Very limited
- Some frustrating levels

[h1]Verdict[/h1]
Attack of the Earthlings is a fun distraction, but it begins to become a bit of a chore as you progress. I didn't enjoy the second-to-last level at all, and now that I'm on the final level I just don't think I can be bothered playing. I'll leave it installed and will probably get around to it one of these days, but on such a short game it's a bit disappointing.

The core mechanics are fun and the humour is great. Production values are high and the game is well balanced. But there's just not enough variation; once you get to about level four you've seen almost all that the game has to offer, and what you haven't seen are most of the frustrating bits.

If you're a fan of turn-based, squad-based strategy, then pick it up for a bit of fun. Just don't expect too much.

review: Okay, played it long enough to have a good enough idea of the game.  It's excellent.  Essentially a fresh take on the x com formula it does both turn based stealth and turn based combat well.  Akin to games like dungeon keeper or the dungeons games, it is one of these games that flips the usual narrative and have you play as the bad guy.  The 'bad guy' here is an alien specy defending their planet from a greedy human corporation.  The human are absolute bumbling idiots and you definitely side with the swarm like aliens.  It is also hilarious.  I wasn't expecting to be so amused by this.  I usually don't like humor with my games but here it works.  The only negative I can think of is that once you finish a playthrough that's pretty much it.  Unlike the newest xcom for instance, nothing is procedurally generated, so when the game ends you pretty much have seen it all BUT there is quite a bit of variety and content before you get there.  If you like xcom or games like invisible inc, mark of the ninja or anything really that combines stealth with  a turn based system, you should get this.
